Several companies like Aarti Steel, Bhubaneswar Power, Ultratech Cement, Shree Cement, JK Laxmi Cement, TS Alloys, Viraj Steel, Utkal Galvanisers and Kamma Re-rollers had urged the Athagarh administration for permission to run their factories during the lockdown period.

Accordingly, Athagarh Sub-Collector Ajambar Mohanty convened a meeting on Wednesday. Company representatives, IICs like Suchitrabirya Das of Khuntuni PS and Bijaya Kumar Bisi of Gurudijhatia PS, people's representatives and media persons attended the meeting.

At the outset, some Mediapersons criticised Aarti Steel for running the plant in deviation of lockdown norms. Social distancing was not maintained and employees did not wash hands regularly.

Some others said that most of the companies use the land, jungle, water of Athagarh but, in return, make the environment polluted and don't engage adequate locals in the plants directly. Even many are not taking up CSR activities in their periphery.

Gurudijhatia PS IIC Bisi said that no doubt the Government has made the guidelines for running the plants but it is doubtful whether they would adhere to these norms. At this juncture, Sub-Collector Mohanty told the company representatives to come with masterplans in compliance with Covid-19 guidelines to run their units within three days.

He said a ground survey local would be conducted subsequently to decide permission of running of the plants.

Title: HP CM directs officers to adhere to guidelines of MHA
Article:
Himachal Chief Minister Jai Ram Thakur on Wednesday directed the officers to adhere to the guidelines of Union Ministry of Home Affairs and said that there should be no laxity till April 20.

Holding a video conference in the wake of coronapandemic with all the Deputy Commissioners, Superintendents of Police and Chief Medical Officers of the State from Shimla, he said all the primary and secondary contacts of Tablighi Jamat should be identified and tested and laxity would not be tolerated in this respect.

Thakur said wearing of masks has been made mandatory for all and disobedience in this regard would be viewed seriously, pointing out that people can also wear home made masks. He urged the NGOs to come forward in providing home-made masks to the people of the State. He said spitting in public places has also been made an offence and the Government would take strict action against violators.

The Chief Minister said plying of trucks and other private carriage carrying essential commodities and vegetables should be allowed with three persons including two drivers and one conductor to ensure adequate availability of essential commodities in the State. He said vehicles should be sanitized and drivers and conductor should be medically checked up. He directed the officers to keep constant check on hoarding and profiteering and strict action must against erring shopkeepers.

Thakur asked the officers that farmers should be allowed to harvest their crops and motivate them for adopting social distancing while working in the fields. He said that steps must also be taken for procurement of their produce so that they do not face any inconvenience due to imposition of curfew. He said that shops dealing with farming inputs should be allowed to open to facilitate the farmers and horticulturists.

Director General of Police S.R. Mardi directed the Superintendents of Police to counter the fake news effectively so that people could be made aware about the factual position.

CM ANNOUNCES HOME BASED TEACHING PROGRAMME FOR STUDENTS

Chief Minister Jai Ram Thakur on Wednesday announced to launch the e-learning and teaching for 10th and 12th standard students of the State through Doordarshan.

"Online learning facility from home will be provided to students under Himachal Doordarshan Gyanshala programme from 17 April, 2020 onwards," he said in a statement, adding that the education department has prepared programme according to the syllabus of HP School Education Board for 10th and 12th classes which would be telecast from 17 April for three hours from 10 AM to 1 PM for different subjects as per the time table.

Thakur urged the teaching faculty, students and their parents to take this benefit by adopting proper social distancing as per the directions of the Union and State Governments.

The Chief Minister also reviewed the ‘Learning from Home- Har Ghar Pathshala’, a home based teaching programme for the students from grades 9 to 12 during the lockdown period of Covid-19.

Reviewing the launch of this programme, the Chief Minister said that to ensure that the studies of the students does not suffer due to the curfew in the State due to corona pandemic, this programme would help the students to get access to online videos and worksheets from their homes on www.education.hp.gov.in and https//cut.ly/hargharpathshala. He said that this programme would start from 16 April, 2020 between 10 am to 1 pm daily till the regular opening of schools.

Thakur said under this programme, all the students would regularly receive daily videos and home work through WhatsApp groups with teachers on important topics. Their homework would be regularly checked by the teachers and also provide feedback, he added.

Education Minister Suresh Bhardwaj said that the education department is also planning to broadcast the study material on TV/Radio/FM to cater every student of the State.

Secretary Information and Public Relations Rajneesh, Secretary Finance Akshay Sood, Special Secretary Education Hemraj Bairwa, Director Higher Education Amarjeet Sharma, Director Information and Public Relations Harbans Singh Brascon and representatives of Doordarshan Shimla were present of the occasion.

AMPLE SUPPLY OF ESSENTIAL COMMODITIES, SAYS CM

In another statement, the Chief Minister said that keeping in view the lockdown, steps were being taken by the State Government to ensure adequate supply of essential commodities in all parts of the State. He said that the supply chain of essential commodities in the State is being maintained effectively so that there is no scarcity of essential commodities during the period of lockdown.

Emphasising that there is sufficient stock of flour, rice, pulses, sugar, edible oils, salt and other grocery items in the state, he said steps are also being taken to ensure availability of milk and bread in adequate quantity and to ensure supply of LPG to all households. He said that availability of medicine is also being ensured in every part of the State besides the fodder for cattle.

Thakur said necessary steps are being taken to check hoarding and profiteering of essential commodities and stern actions being taken against the defaulters.

He urged the general public not to panic purchasing and unnecessary stocking as adequate supply of essential commodities was being done in the State.

Title: 73rd Himachal Day celebrated at the Ridge Shimla
Article:
Himachal Pradesh Chief Minister Jai Ram Thakur on Wednesday unfurled the national flag at the Ridge in Shimla marking the 73rd Himachal Day in a low-key affair amid the Covid-19 pandemic.

The celebrations were modest as Thakur presided over the symbolic State-level function and and took salute from the police contingent.

Education Minister Suresh Bhardwaj, Shimla Mayor Satya Kondal, Deputy Mayor Shelander Chauhan, Chief Secretary Anil Khachi, Director General of Police S R Mardi were also present during the function along with the Chief Minister. Felicitating the residents of the State, Governor Bandaru Dattatreya unfurled the Tricolour in Raj Bhavan complex by keeping social distance. Officials of Raj Bhavan were also present on the occasion.

The Governor also greeted former Chief Ministers Virbhadra Singh, Shanta Kumar and Prem Kumar Dhumal on the occasion of Himachal Day while talking to them over the phone, an official spokesperson said.

Dattatraya also asked about their well being and spoke on various topics in view of the prevailing circumstances and hoped that the country would emerge from the coronavirus pandemic and life would be normal soon.

Following independence in 1947, the Chief Commissioner's province of Himachal Pradesh was created on April 15, 1948 which has since been marked each year as Himachal Day.

Title: Punjab Cong seeks tax relief for small, micro industries
Article:
Pointing that 42 days of continuous lockdown has pushed small and micro enterprises into unprecedented crisis, Punjab Pradesh Congress Committee president Sunil Jakhar on Wednesday demanded from the Central Government to intervene immediately to provide help to MSMEs during shut down.

At the same time, PPCC chief demanded that at least wages equal to 50 days of job should be urgently transferred to MGNREGA workers bank accounts in advance and work from them should be got done later since they had no money at present due to the ongoing lockdown to arrange food for their families.

Jakhar said that small and micro enterprises make significant contribution to the economy and millions of people are employed with it, “but with the limited financial resources, this sector is in serious crisis these days. It is not enough for the Central Government to defer loan recovery for just three months because after three months’ closure, the sector will not have the capital to pay the installments”.

He also said that the Centre has also asked the sector to provide regular salaries to its employees.

“It is imperative that the Central Government give exemption to small and micro enterprises in the interest of loans and other taxes for up to one year to prevent them from a fatal closure,” he added.

Terming the central government's contribution of Rs 500 to JanDhan accounts as a cruel joke to the poor, Jakhar said that in this way, the Centre was putting people in more crisis as thousands of people were braving heat in queue to draw only Rs 500 from the banks most of which were not following COVID related advisories also.

Therefore, it is necessary to transfer one-time and sufficient money in their bank accounts to prevent crowding that defeats the basic purpose of lockdown, he said.

Title: 50 female students each of Govt BSc Nursing, GNN training centres deployed
Article:
For the control and management of Covid-19 pandemic, 50 female students each of Government BSc Nursing and GNN training centres have been deployed in Bhopal and Indore districts till June 30.

These girls will work under the Chief Medical and Health Officer Girls will have to join within three days from the date of order.

Commissioner Public Health and Family Welfare Faiz Ahmed Kidwai informed that these services have been taken under ESMA. Disciplinary action can be taken against the girls who do not follow the order. This service will be purely temporary. The honorarium for the selected girls for the post of staff nurse for this service will be Rs 20,000 per month.

Transport, food and lodging will be made available by the department to the girls at their place of duty.

Also, all necessary Personal Protective Equipment (PPE) will be made available to the nurses.

If the student given the order is already working in another district, then instructions have been issued by the district administration to grant special travel permission for joining.

Title: Covid hospitals open in K’pada, Balangir
Article:
A 100-bed capacity COVID Hospital with a 10-bed ICU and ventilator support facilities was made operational with the support of SUM Hospital in Kendrapada district on Tuesday.

ECG and X-rays facilities were also available in the COVID hospital set up at the Chatta-based Government Polytechnic, informed Kendrapada Collector Samarth Verma.

As many as four doctors, 15 nurses and five technical staffs have been engaged in the hospital, added Verma. While the SUM Hospital authorities will work as health operator, the district administration has taken the task of providing sanitation and security. The Mahanadi Coalfields Limited has provided funds for the hospital.

A MoU was signed on Monday between the Kendrapara Collector and SUM Hospital Superintendent Dr Pusparaj Samantasinhar for the hospital.

Similarly, a 200-bed COVID hospital was launched at the KISS campus in Balangir by district Collector Arindum Dakua on Tuesday. The hospital is being managed by KIMS.

A three-tier treatment facility has been arranged in the district. The patients having mild symptoms would be treated at the Corona Care Centre at the primary level and with moderate level symptoms; the patient would be treated at the COVID Health Centre.

And those having serious and positive symptoms would be treated at this COVID Hospital which has all the facilities for virus infected patients, informed Dakua.

Presently, the hospital is functioning with 100 beds but it would be expanded later.

A total of 280 swabs samples were collected from the district and sent to the Regional Research Medical Centre in Bhubaneswar for tests and all the 90 reports, which have come so far have tested negative.

Title: Police launch initiative ‘Geet Hum Gayenge Corona Tumhe Harayenge’
Article:
With every passing day to remain encouraged and manage stress is most important in the time of never seen epidemic Coronavirus and to address this Indore police came with unique initiative with a programme on wireless sets ‘Geet Hum Gayenge Corona Tumhe Harayenge’ every day at 11 in the morning.

The initiative was taken by IG Indore Vivek Sharma in which police officials and personnel share poems and songs on wireless sets every day at 11 am which helps in motivation among the group and it also helps their creativity to be showcased and introduced among the peers.

On April 12 IG Sharma started the programme by singing ‘Hum Honge Kaamyaab’ In the programme

which was held on Wednesday reciting of inspirational song and poems gave new energy to each other and also give message to the residents of Indore that to defeat Corona, they should stay in all the houses and follow the lockdown. The lyrics of some of these songs and poems were ‘ Teer Alag, Talwar Alag, Alag Humara Bhala hai, Indore Tum Befikr Raho Sadakon Par Tainat Tumhara Rakhwala Hai’.

The Subedar of the Traffic Police Uzma Khan recited a patriotic song " Chowk Par Khada Jawan Shivaji Aur Rana Hai, Rakht Nahi Nason Main Daudta Janseva Ka Raanga Hai”

Among others song and poems by police officials and personnel were ‘ Lete Hum Yamrath Ke Pahhiyon Ke Aage, Indore Nahi Ghusne Denge, Saugandh Hume Is Mitti Ki Hum Desh Nahi Denge’.

Title: No social distancing in Sunabeda market
Article:
Though social distancing is ought to be maintained strictly during the lockdown in wake of the coronavirus outbreak, it is being blatantly flouted at the Jagannath Market in HAL Township under the Sunabeda Municipality.

But there is no enforcement of the lockdown guidelines by the municipality or police officials in the market which opens from 7 am to 11 am. More than 1,500 people are depending on this market. Neither scores of customers nor the vegetable and non-vegetarian sellers are maintaining the necessary physical distance or wearing masks which have been made mandatory by the Government.

The police, HAL security guards and social activists are remaining silent spectators instead of reprimanding them or sensitising them about the deadly coronavirus disease which does not discriminate and can infecting anyone.

Title: Trucks carrying petroleum products allowed to operate
Article:
A meeting presided over by Jagatsinghpur district Collector SK Mohapatra took some important decisions regarding transportation of petroleum products during the lockdown period.

IOCL, LPG Terminal Chief Manager AK Tripathy said since transportation of petroleum products has been interrupted due to the non-availability of the trucks despite the exemption during lockdown, the operation of food and packaging industries and the units manufacturing medical appliances like syringes, pouches, hospital disposables, test tubes, breakers, pipettes, etc. have been severely affected.

Sumanta Kumar Biswal, president of the Paradip Truck Owners’ Association, informed that they have been able to keep only 50 vehicles ready with their staffs.

Santosh Kumar Pattnaik, president of the Jagatsinghpur District Truck Owners’ Association expressed concern that some trucks carrying essentials were halted en route on Jagatsinghpur border.

After a detailed discussion, it was decided that a few trucks will be engaged for transport of Polymer Petro Chemical Product to plants within the State. There would not be unnecessary delay in loading of the product. The time of loading and departure of the vehicles would be informed to the ADM, Paradip and the Additional SP, Paradip. The truck associations would submit the registration numbers of vehicles. Roadside dhabas and garages would remain open. The IOCL authorities would instruct the petrol pump owner to arrange food and water for the drivers and the helpers.

Both the owner of the vehicle and the IOCL would provide the staffs of the vehicle with masks, gloves and sanitisers. To overcome the apprehension of social ostracism, the associations would facilitate accommodation to drivers and helpers in Paradip town.

Title: U'kote cops act strongly against lockdown violators
Article:
The Umarkote police here are in no mood to spare the people violating lockdown. Police seized 30 bikes and a car and collected Rs 1,200 as fine from the person not wearing a mask on Tuesday.

A team of police personnel headed by SDPO Hemanta Kumar Padhy swung into action in the town to enforce the nationwide lockdown. However, private vehicles having valid pass were given relaxation.

Only goods carrying essential commodities and emergency vehicles were allowed inside the town. Barricades had been placed in the Chattisghar-Odisha border to prevent the movement of vehicles. Nabarangpur Sub-Collector Bhaskar Raita who is the administrator of Umarkote Municipality accompanied the cops in implementing the COVID-19 protocol strictly in the town. The Sub-collector also visited different shops to verify the rate chats of essential commodities and urged the shop keepers to maintain social distancing during the business hour.

"Since the inception of lockdown, we have not shown any laxity. Those engaged in essential work are only spared that too after seeing their valid permission and I-card," said Umarkote IIC Umesh Chandra Sahu. Among others, Umarkote Tehisldar Himanchala Majhi and Umarkote Municipality Executive Officer Upendra Dip were also in the team.

Title: ‘Deploy military forces at religious places'
Article:
The Bharatiya Bikash Parishad has requested the Union Government to deploy military or paramilitary forces at all mosques, churches, temples and other religious institutions during the lockdown for effective control of deadly coronavirus across the country.

Parishad president Surendra Panigrahi has written to Prime Minister Narendra Midi in this regard.

The letter mentioned that spread of the deadly virus has been proportionately controlled in the country compared to the rest of the world because of the Janata Curfew and the subsequent 21-day lockdown.

The Parishad wholeheartedly supported the further extension of lockdown period till May 3.

The letter, however, alleged that some of the Chief Ministers are playing vote bank politics in the name of religion. The

Tablighi Jamaat congregation held in Delhi caused of manifold rise in COVID positive cases in the country.

The Parishad expressed its concern saying that some miscreants taking advantage of the countrywide lockdown grossly violated the provisions of Disaster Management Act and Epidemic Act by spreading Covid-19 deadly virus in the country deliberately with the tacit support of the State administrations since the enforcement of law and order are vested with the State Government.

"The basic duty of a democratic Government is to save the precious lives of its citizens irrespective of caste and religion," it argued.

Title: Rath Yatra may be held amid curbs
Article:
For the first time in the history, the chariots of Lord Jagannath and His siblings will roll on the Badadanda (Grand Road) here during Rath Yatra probably in the absence devotees if the COVID-19 situation does not improve in near future.

Jagannath Temple’s senior servitor Binayak Das Mohapatra said this while informing that the annual Chandan Yatra of Lord Jagannath on April 26 would be held at the Narendra Puskarani (pond) without participation of devotees in view of the coronavirus outbreak.

The 21-day water sports festival of the Trinity, which begins on the auspicious occasion of Akshaya Tritiya, would be conducted with all the rituals as per the tradition. This apart, the process of construction of the chariots of the deities would begin with ‘Rath Anukula’ on Akshaya Tritiya, Mohapatra said.

“If the COVID-19 situation continues to remain the same till the time of Rath Yatra, the festival will also be held without participation of devotees. But there is no question of cancellation of the two festivals. The state Government will take the right decision at the right time,” he said.

Slicing of wood logs used in construction of the chariots began on Ram Navami. Construction of the chariots would begin on Akshaya Tritiya as per the tradition, but social distancing would be ensured during the work as per the Government’s COVID-19 lockdown guidelines, said another senior servitor, Rajat Kumar Pratihari.

“Nevertheless, if any miracle happens by the grace of the ‘Lord of the Universe’ and the virus is defeated, Rath Yatra will be held in the presence of His devotees as always,” he added.

Title: Mass screening, testing on at various places in Punjab
Article:
More than three weeks after the curfew was imposed across Punjab amidst coronavirus scare, the State Government has initiated the process of mass screening and testing. A day after starting the rapid testing facility from Mohali and Jalandhar districts, the Government has started testing of all residents in Patiala’s municipal limits, and house-to-house screening in Amritsar. Punjab’s tally of corona positive cases stands at 186 on Wednesday with maximum 56 and 25 positive cases reported from Mohali and Jalandhar respectively — the two districts having the maximum of eight hotspots.

Even as Patiala and Amritsar has reported three and 11 cases respectively till date, the decisions, taken by the respective District Administrations, was aimed at checking the community transmission, and further spread of the deadly virus.

Unable to trace the source of infection of the three positive cases reported so far in the district, Patiala Administration has decided to screen all its residents in the municipal limits — becoming the first district to do so. As per the Health Department, all the three cases in Patiala neither had any travel history nor they have come in contact with any other COVID-19 patient — a development indicating at the possibility of community transmission.

On late Tuesday evening, a 50-year-old resident of Safabadi Gate of Patiala city, a social worker involved in distributing ration at various places in the city, had tested positive for coronavirus.

Alarmed, the District Administration has put around 500 people under home isolation, besides taking the samples for testing of his close contacts. Besides the herculean task of contact tracing, the Administration is also scrambling to trace the source of his infection.

“We have ordered the screening of the entire population living within the jurisdiction of the Patiala municipal corporation (MC) to avoid further spread of the infection. Special attention will be given to those exhibiting symptoms of coronavirus,” said Patiala Deputy Commissioner Kumar Amit.

The DC has also imposed ban on the distribution of langar in the city except the Red Cross Society.

“As per preliminary steps, we have sealed the area around his residence. We are conducting contact tracing,” said a government official.

Meanwhile, Amritsar Administration has started three-day house-to-house screening, and as many as 53,865 persons were examined from 12,401 households.

“The three-day door-to-door screening operation against Covid-19, launched by the District Administration involving the departments of Health, Police and Municipal Corporation, has been completed,” said the state Special Chief Secretary Karan Bir Singh Sidhu.

Sidhu said that the hotspot areas, from where positive cases of Bhai Nirmal Singh Khalsa and Jaswinder Singh were reported, have been all covered, besides the Jodh Nagar, ESI hospital vicinity, Kangra Colony, Mustafabad, among others.

“One suspected case was found, whose test report has come out to be negative. The entire operation was conducted by 42 teams, managed by 10 Supervisory Officers,” he added.

Title: Spit in public place, pay Rs 500 fine
Article:
Amid the COVID-19 threat, the Ganjam district administration on Wednesday banned spitting in public places.

In a letter to district administration officials, Ganjam Collector Vijay Amruta Kulange said, “Spitting in public places shall be prohibited and violators will be levied a fine of up to Rs 500.”

This apart, masks have been made compulsory to cover the mouth and nose in view of the virus outbreak. If anyone violates, the concerned person pays a fine of Rs 200.

No persons shall be allowed to walk in groups of two or more people, the letter added. It is necessary for everyone to maintain a distance of at least two meter between each other at all times.

Issuing guidelines for shopkeepers, the letter stated that they should put up boards with phrase ‘No mask, no grocery/vegetables/medicine/fruits’.

No sale of gutkha, paan, chewing gum and any food items promoting spitting shall be permitted in the district during the lockdown period, the letter said.

Title: ‘Aarogya Setu becomes world's fastest app to reach 5 crore downloads’
Article:
The Centre’s mobile app, Aarogya Setu, developed for tracking COVID-19 patients, has become the world’s fastest app to reach 50 million downloads in just 13 days, NITI Aayog CEO Amitabh Kant said on Wednesday.

Prime Minister Narendra Modi in his address to the nation on April 14 appealed to people to download the app.

“Telephone took 75 years to reach 50 million users, radio 38 yrs, television 13 yrs, Internet 4 yrs, Facebook 19 months, Pokemon Go 19 days. AarogyaSetu, India’s app to fight COVID-19 has reached 50 mn users in just 13 days-fastest ever globally for an App,” Mr. Kant said in his tweet.

The application alerts people if any known or person in their vicinity has tested positive.

District administration has been asking all educational institutions, departments etc to encourage downloading of the app.

The app was developed under a committee set up by the Prime Minister’s Office with active involvement of NITI Aayg and Ministry of Electronics and IT.

According to sources, Tata Consultancy Services is working on testing and some of the other aspects, while Tech Mahindra and the Mahindra group is working with the committee on the next version of this application and leveraging next generation technologies like AI, machine learning, data science.

Tech Mahindra is also working on expanding the reach of Aarogya Setu on all types of phones.

The current version of Aarogya Setu app is fit for use on smartphones only.

Title: Power cuts in Baleswar add to lockdown woes
Article:
Amidst lockdown the residents while are forced to be indoors, frequent unscheduled power cuts by the Nesco had proved to be adding to their woes as mercury was soaring and day temperature had been hovering around 40 degree Celsius.

Frequent power cuts, for unknown reasons, are not only experienced in the urban patches, they are also in the rural areas. The residents are facing untold woes as the supply is erratic and at time the cut period is about an hour.

The poor, especially the infants and elderly people, having no other means of electricity supply, are the worst sufferers.

Due to the Corona attributed lockdown while all the industrial and commercial establishments are closed and load on the grid has reduced, the residents expressed their dismay over the power cuts.

For power supply in the town while the department had two 2 feeders and 6 structures in view of growing demand and load, three more feeders and four structures have been made.

Nesco Superintendent Engineer Braja Sundar Parida has a different version to say about the domestic consumption.

“Despite closure of industrial units and commercial establishments, surprisingly the domestic consumption of electricity has gone up compared to previous years. Data says the total consumption has gone up by 2.5 million unit than last year. It is believed since the people are forced to stay in they must be using all electrical appliances,” said Parida.

“The power cuts were made as substations were erected to cater the additional power requirements of COVID-19 quarantine centres. In the town two sub stations were installed in FM College commerce block,” he said, adding that all the urgently required modifications and alteration have been completed.

Title: 5T Secy, DC visit Sambalpur DHH
Article:
5T Secretary V Karthikeyan Pandian and Development Commissioner Suresh Mahapatra visited Sambalpur on Wednesday to take stock of the proposed Covid 19 hospital construction at the District Headquarters Hospital.

At present, work for a 200-bed Covid ward with a 40-bed ICU is going on war footing basis in the DHH.

During a 30 -minute stay inside the hospital, both directed the local administration to expedite the work so that it could be come to use soon.

Meanwhile, some people of Sambalpur and Mission VSSIMSAR have protested against the corona hospital in the DHH as it would create another threat to the nearby residents. The latter has also filed a PIL in the High Court, which has served notices to the Government. The next date of hearing has been fixed for May 4.

Title: Artists create covid sculpture
Article:
To create awareness about the danger of Covid-19 infection, artists of the Odisha Progressive Group made a sculpture of the novel coronavirus here on Wednesday.

Priyaranjan Baral, Srikrushna Behera, Sudeep Barik and Bibhuti Maharana created a replica of the coronavirus in front of the Capital police station.

The replica was made using Plaster of Paris and painted in the hues of orange and red. The sculpture is about 7 feet in height and about 5 feet in width. The structure sits atop a log of wood and serves as a reminder to people passing by to take all precautions to keep themselves protected.

Title: Haryana fears losing Rs 4,600 crore revenue
Article:
In the backdrop of ongoing coronavirus-triggered lockdown bringing all economic activities to a grinding halt, Haryana Government on Wednesday feared losing a whopping Rs 4,600 crore revenue in April. The stamp duty alone generated Rs 600 crore revenue every month in Haryana but no money is expected to accrue to the State coffer on this count in April as no land deals and other property transactions are taking place amid the lockdown.

Chief Minister Manohar Lal Khattar on Wednesday too voiced the revenue loss fear during a televised address on the day to the people of the state.

Kosh Muloo Dand, said Khattar, citing the crucial economic mantra occurring in Kautiliyan Arthshastra, which implies "the treasury is the backbone of administration", and pointed to the revenue losses that the state has been facing due to the lockdown.

We were expecting a Stamp duty of Rs 600 crore, but as no property transactions are taking place, no money will come. We are expecting only about

Rs 100 crore from Excise Duty as against nearly Rs 1,000 crore while from nearly Rs 782 crore from VAT collections, a maximum of Rs 100 crore is expected, he said.

The Chief Minister said as against Rs 6,200 crore monthly revenue income from various sources estimated in the Budget, a maximum of Rs 1,600 crore is expected due to the coronavirus-triggered lockdown, which has brought all economic activities to a grinding halt. We are falling short by nearly Rs 4600 crore.

Khattar said some expenditures like salaries and pensions are fixed and these have to be met. Nearly Rs 1,850 crore goes towards meeting salaries of government employees, Rs 750 crore towards pensions, Rs 650 crore towards social security pension that includes the money for the old, widows and physically challenged persons.

An amount of Rs 1,700 crore goes towards servicing debts which the state has borrowed.

In view of the current situation, the BJP-JJP Government in the State had also announced a special financial aides to help the poor and people in low income groups like daily wagers, labourers, street vendors and construction workers who have been adversely hit. Meanwhile, with mustard and wheat procurement respectively commencing from April 15 and 20, Khattar reiterated that we will procure every single grain of the farmers.

He appealed to the 'arhatiyas' or commission agents to extend a helping hand to farmers during this time of crisis.

He asserted that it was only a matter of time before we win the battle against corona.

In our country, everyone is fighting this battle. The problem is big. It is like a traffic signal which has turned red where all of us have stopped and are waiting for it to turn green and then we will move on. No matter how much challenge it throws, we will overcome it and come out of it.

The Chief Minister also gave detailed information about the benefits transferred under the schemes being run by the Centre and the State Government during the last 25 days amid Corona Crisis. He said that financial assistance has been given to about 23 lakh beneficiaries including 12.50 lakh beneficiaries of the Mukhya Mantri Parivar Samridhi Yojna, 3.50 lakh construction workers, 6.4 lakh BPL families and 1,00,000 unorganized labour. He said that till now an amount of Rs 438 crore has been transferred to the accounts of 13 lakh beneficiaries and the financial assistance to the left out beneficiaries will soon be transferred.

He said that for the corona warriors including doctors, nurses, paramedical staff, testing staff, class IV employees, and all those who come in direct contact with Covid-19 patients, an amount of Rs 10 crore has been reserved and the State Government has already announced to double their salaries. Apart from this, ex-gratia scheme has also been announced for them.

Title: Spitting banned in UT, violators to be prosecuted
Article:
The UT Administration on Wednesday issued order banning the spitting of any chewable tobacco or non-tobacco product, sputum in public offices, workplaces, offices, factories and other establishments with immediate effect. The decision in this regard was taken during the review meeting held by Punjab Governor and UT Administrator VP Singh Badnore. UT Adviser Manoj Parida said, spitting has been banned in the city and violators will be criminally prosecuted.

Earlier, the Administration had banned the sale of chewing gum, bubble gum, pan masala and other allied products for the next three months. The precautionary measure was announced midst fear that the virus is present in saliva and spitting of chewing gum and other allied products could spread the Coronavirus.

During the meeting, the UT Administrator directed all the three medical institutions namely PGIMER, GMSH-16 and GMCH-32 to ensure that the safety of the doctors and health workers be given top priority.

Title: Government issues helpline number for urban, rural areas
Article:
In a bid to ensure uninterrupted supply of drinking water in the torrid summer, the State Government on Wednesday issued helpline numbers for both rural and urban areas.

Panchayati Raj and Drinking Water Minister Pratap Jena said people in urban areas can dial toll-free number 18003456783 to inform about any issue related to drinking water. The toll-free number for rural area is 1916. The Government would supply drinking water in large tankers to the areas that lack drinking water facilities.

Control Rooms have been opened at engineer and Junior Engineer offices, division offices and sub-division offices across districts to receive complaints regarding drinking water. If required, tube wells would be installed in rural areas following proposal of the concerned district Collector.

Besides, the concerned officials have been directed to start renovation of all defunct tube wells in rural and urban areas on war-footing basis, the Minister added.

Title: Lockdown right medicine but side effects painful: Badal
Article:
Punjab’s five-time Chief Minister Parkash Singh Badal on Wednesday said that the nationwide lockdown was “the right medicine at the right time but with painful side effects which need to be attended to immediately before they become more dangerous than the disease itself”.

“The poor, especially the daily wage earners, are the worst affected by these side effects and need immediate care. However, the other low income groups are not far behind,” said Badal adding that the middle classes were now beginning to find these side effects hard to cope with.

Badal said that the war on coronvirus needs to be fought with the same spirit as was seen during India’s struggle for freedom “as the challenge has the same gravity for every citizen”.

Describing hunger and poverty, plus unemployment and economic slowdown as three immediate, mid-term and long-term side effects of the pandemic, Badal called for a “graded strategy to fight all three”.

Welcoming ‘the gradual exit strategies’ announced, Badal appealed to the people, especially the farmers, farm labour and workers in other fields, to be extra-careful and “fully respect and obey the guidelines issued by the government”.

Badal, saying that lockdown was the only option available to the Government, said that “six weeks is a long time for the poor to survive without income, and more particularly, without regular supply of food at their door”.

“Governments must provide safe modes of travel to the migrants and others to go back to their homes, especially if the lockdown is to be extended further,” said Badal describing “containing and fighting unemployment” as the urgent long-term necessity.

Badal also emphasized the need for ensuring hassle free harvesting and procurement of the wheat crop saying that the governments must ensure that no one connected with these operations is harassed.

He urged the Centre to give a “significant bonus on wheat, in addition, the government must think of subsiding agricultural inputs in a major way”

Title: B'ngir, K’mal, M'bhanj get Covid hospitals
Article:
COVID-19 Hospitals are coming up throughout the State after the initiative of Chief Minister Naveen Patnaik in this regard. Two hospitals, managed by the KIMS, Bhubaneswar and financed by the Government have become operational in Balangir and Kandhamal districts from April 14 and one in Mayurbhanj district from April 15.

The hospital in Kandhamal has 150 beds while in Mayurbhanj and Balangir the hospitals have 200 beds each. Both Balangir and Mayurbhanj hospitals are functioning from the KISS campuses.

The processing for a 10-bed ICU in Phulbani COVID Hospital is in progress while work on a 20-bed ICU in Balangir and Mayurbhanj each will be completed in a week. The KIMS, Bhubaneswar has taken the responsibility of operation of these hospitals.

About 60 employees, including doctors, nurses, pharmacists, biomedical engineers, electrical engineers and housekeeping staffs, of KIMS have joined these hospitals.

These Covid hospitals will be managed under the direct supervision of KIIT University Pro-Chancellor Dr Subrat Acharya.

KIIT and KISS founder Dr Achyuta Samanta has thanked Chief Minister Patnaik for giving the opportunity to the KIMS to open the Covid-19 Hospitals in three tribals-dominated districts.

Title: Pradhan happy over crude shipping to Paradip
Article:
Union Petroleum Minister Dharmendra Pradhan on Tuesday held discussions with Roseneft CEO Igor Ivanovich Sechin through videoconference.

He thanked Sechin for shipping crude oil to the Paradip Port for the first time, the MoU for which was signed between the (IOCL and the Roseneft in March.

Pradhan also held discussions on the concerning scenario in the global energy sector and increasing cooperation between the Indian companies and Roseneft.

The Minister also held discussions on the effects of coronavirus pandemic on the world energy and gas sector and the OPEC and Russia decreasing production of oil.

Title: Punjab starts pool testing of suspected corona patients
Article:
Punjab Government has launched a pooled procedure for the investigation of suspected Covid-19 patients in the State’s Viral Research Diagnostic Lab (VRDL) at Government Medical College in Patiala and Amritsar.

“The results are very promising and no evidence of false results has been found during tests at Viral Research Diagnostic Labs (VRDL) of the states,” said the State Medical Education and Research Minister Om Prakash Soni on Wednesday adding that the technique is expected to increase Covid-19 testing capacity four folds.

Feasibility study of this technique has already been conducted and it is an Indian Council of Medical Research (ICMR) recommended technique, said Soni.

Soni said that the pooled testing algorithm involves the PCR screening of a specimen pool comprising multiple individual patient specimens, followed by individual testing (pool de-convolution) only if a pool screens positive. While all individual samples in a negative pool, are regarded as negative. This technique increases the capacity of the laboratories to screen increased numbers of samples and also results in substantial cost savings when a large proportion of pools tests negative, he said. He said that pooled testing detects viral RNA in samples very accurately and helps maximize existing resources. It can really save costs while enhancing the capacity enormously, he added.

Researchers from Germany and Israel have already validated this method and ICMR had issued the advisory in this regard on April 13. The labs in Punjab had immediately taken up this challenge and have delivered the results, thereby saving not only on costs but also on the test kits which are in limited supply the world over.

Title: Ollywood stars release video song on corona
Article:
The State’s film fraternity has come forward to create awareness about the COVID-19 situation with a video song called “Hope”.

The song titled “Jay Jay Jay Ho Odisha” is an initiative of Sidharth TV, Sidharth Music and Sarthak FM. Singer Shasank Sekhar has lent his voice for the song with lyrics written by Arun Mantri.

The song starts with a message of Chief Minister Naveen Patnaik saying blessings of Lord Jagannath and sacrifice of all the people would help the State win the battle against the deadly virus. The video features several Ollywood personalities, including Arindam Roy, Siddhant Mohapatra, Sabyasachi Mishra, Swaraj, Mahasweta Ray, Anu Chaudhury, Elina Samantray, Bhoomika Dash and Prem Anand. The video was shot at homes of the film personalities and carries the message that the critical situation shall pass with awareness and a pledge to maintain social distancing.

Governor Ganeshi Lal and sand artist Sudarshan Pattnaik have also been featured in the video.

Title: Delay in vaccination manageable: Experts
Article:
Given the lockdown, it is obvious that there would be delayed vaccination, but such a vaccination is manageable, say experts, suggesting parents to stay home and not rush to hospitals.

Associate Professor, Department Pediatrics, MKCG Medical College and Hospital, Dr Sunil Agarwalla says, “Primary vaccines are important however it can be delayed by two to three months or more depending on the current situation. It is important to stay safe at home and follow guidelines of COVID-19 as delayed vaccination will not cause disruption. Additionally, parental anxiety needs be curbed by incorporating measures comprising good behavioral patterns with the child, limiting the screen time, avoiding fast food, ensuring adequate nutrition intake, in order to help boost the immunity of the child.”

“Rushing to hospitals right now for scheduled vaccinations is not advisable as it can put you at a risk of contracting the virus and simultaneously passing it to other healthcare professionals and caregivers,” adds Dr Agarwalla.

Title: Punjab Govt ties up with Ola for app to issue e-passes to farmers
Article:
Punjab Government has, in collaboration with OLA, developed a unique centralized automated logic-based technology platform for issuance of e-passes to the 17 lakh odd farmers in the State, along with online management and regulation of all trolleys and vehicular movement in the mandis.

The initiative has been adopted by the Punjab Mandi Board to launch an e-pass system with the help of Department of Governance Reforms and Public Grievances, in an effort to further streamline the procurement operations in the backdrop of the Covid-19 crisis.

The OLA app, installed on the mobile phones of the farmers, shall also alert them on the rush spots at the mandi gates to check overcrowding. App’s centralized dashboard, a unique initiative aligned to the social distancing guidelines of the Union Ministry of Health and Family Welfare, shall also give alerts on pass issuance, expiry and validation.

This unique system enables Market Committees Secretaries across the State to generate mobility passes for farmers by the purchase centers as well as by the ahrtiyas. The software generates the required number of passes automatically, based on historic data available with the Mandi Board.

All arhtiyas shall be provided with one pass for one trolley of wheat. The passes for a particular day are provided three days before to the arhtiyas, to prevent any kind of rush. This automated technology solution removes all unnecessary bias and opportunities of favouritism, thus bringing in transparency to the process.

The arhtiyas shall distribute these mobility passes to their farmers to enable the latter to come on the designated date at the concerned purchase center. The farmer shall also receive an SMS with pass number and link to download the app.

“Apart from the e-pass system, an mPass system has also been developed in the ePMB mobile application. A Unicode SMS is sent to every arhtiya at the time of pass issuance. The arhtiya can allocate the passes to trolley drivers through in-built mPass system. The drivers can then download the mPass using the SMS received on his number, and use this mPass at various Police Nakas for permitted mobility,” said the state Additional Chief Secretary, Development, Vishwajit Khanna.

Khanna said that the online vehicular management shall help the Board maintain law and order protocols as well as DHS guidelines in the mandis.

Punjab Mandi Board secretary and Governance Reforms special secretary Ravi Bhagat said that with features such as geo-tagging, geo-hashing, alerts and emergency support, this unique technology solution will help the government manage mandi operations well.

Title: Relaxations on anvil for zero case districts after April 20
Article:
The Uttarakhand Government is planning to provide relaxations in the ongoing lockdown after April 20 in the districts of the State with no case of novel Coronavirus (COVID-19). As of now, there are seven such districts in the State where not even a single case has been reported. Meanwhile, no new case of the disease was reported in the State by the health department on Wednesday. The State has so far reported 37 patients of the disease out of whom 9 patients have recovered and discharged from the hospitals.

The additional secretary, medical health and family welfare department, Yugal Kishore Pant, said that at present there seven districts in the state where no case of COVID-19 has been reported and some relaxations in lockdown would be given in these districts after April 20.

He added that apart from them there are five districts where 1 to 17 cases have been reported and here too some relaxation could be given after April 20. Pant said that district Dehradun with 18 cases so far is in red zone and here no relaxation from lockdown would be given . Chamoli, Rudraprayag, Tehri, Uttarkashi, Champawat, Bageshwar and Pithoragarh districts have so far reported no case of the disease. Dehradun district with 18 patients of the disease is at top in the state while Nainital and Haridwar districts have so far reported eight and five cases respectively.

In Udham Singh Nagar four patients have so far been found while one patient each has been reported from Pauri and Almora districts.

Pant informed that sample reports of 90 suspected patients were received by the department till 5.30 pm on Wednesday and all of them were found negative for the disease.

He said that reports of 354 samples are still awaited. Pant said that the rate of sample collection in the State has gained momentum with department collecting 239 samples on Wednesday.

The authorities have so far taken swab samples of 2413 suspected patients for COVID-19 test. A total of 1,833 people are under institutional quarantine while 4672 suspected patients in hospital isolation.

The authorities have sent 53,151 people are in home quarantine in different parts of the State.

In an advisory, the State Government has asked people not to consume and spit smokeless tobacco in public. The chewing of tobacco and supari incites a strong desire to spit due to which the chances of spread of disease increase.

Title: GMDC Lab to start testing of COVID-19 soon
Article:
After the consent given by the Indian Council of Medical Research (ICMR), the microbiology lab of the Government Doon Medical College (GDMC) hospital here is gearing itself to start testing for COVID-19. The Principal of the GDMC, Dr Ashutosh Sayana, said that the necessary equipment has been installed in the laboratory and training to the staff has been given for testing of swab samples of suspected patients. The medical college is now awaiting written confirmation from the ICMR for starting the tests.

In the State, the testing facilities of COVID-19 are available only at the laboratory of department of microbiology of Government Medical College, Haldwani and All India Institute of Medical Sciences (AIIMS), Rishikesh. Till last month Lab of Haldwani was the only facility in the state for COVID-19. On March 31, the AIIMS Rishikesh also started doing the tests. The ICMR has also approved the lab of Indian Institute of Petroleum (IIP) to conduct the test but here the machine has not been installed yet. In private sector, Ahuja lab in Dehradun has also been authorised to conduct tests.

The confirmatory test of the COVID-19 involves detection of Ribo Nucleic Acid (RNA) of the virus by the PCR method.

Title: Khattar appeals Arhtiyas to help purchase every grain
Article:
Haryana Chief Minister Manohar Lal Khattar on Wednesday urged the Arhtiyas of the State to come forward and support the efforts of the State Government in purchasing every single grain of the farmers. Addressing the people during the live telecast of 'Haryana Aaj' programme here, Khattar said for the convenience of the farmers during this difficult period, the procurement centres for mustard have been increased substantially from 66 last year to 143. He said that today about 7000 farmers were called on the first day of the mustard procurement to sell their produce.

He said that Arhtiyas can play an important role in the purchase of farmers’ crops by visiting each procurement centre and helping them in selling their crops. He said that the coordinated efforts of the State Government and the Arhtiyas will definitely make it easy for the farmers and the labourers in the procurement process in this time of crisis. The Chief Minister said that helping the poor should be our topmost priority at this time.

CM SPEAKS TO FARMERS

As Government procurement of Mustard began in the mandis, for the first time Haryana Chief Minister, Manohar Lal Khattar asked farmers to recount their experiences of their first day in the mandis while speaking to them over the phone during the Haryana Aaj programme.

During the interaction, Chief Minister assured the farmers that they will not face any difficulties even in future whether it is for the purchase of mustard or wheat, during procurement in the mandis.

The Chief Minister appealed to the farmers who came to the mandis with their mustard produce to inform other farmers as well that they should bring their produce to the mandis to sell only on the days allotted to them.

TEN THOUSAND METRIC TON OF MUSTARD PROCURED

Additional Chief Secretary, Haryana Agriculture and Farmers Welfare Department, Sanjeev Kaushal on Wednesday said about ten thousand metric tons of Mustard was procured from about 4500 farmers on the first day by calling 25 farmers each in the morning and afternoon at all centres.

Title: Rawals of Badrinath and Kedarnath shrines to remain present
Article:
The suspense over the presence of chief priests (Rawals) of Badrinath and Kedarnath shrines during the opening of the portals ended on Wednesday with Uttarakhand Government assuring that arrangements for their return to the State are being made. The Rawal of Badrinath, Ishwari Prasad Namboodri, is at his native village in Kerala while the Rawal of Kedarnath, Bhima Shankar Lingam, is at Nanded in Maharashtra. The portals of Kedarnath shrine are scheduled to open on April 29 while that of Badrinath are opening a day later on April 30.

As per the tradition, the presence of chief priests is necessary during the ceremonial opening of Badrinath and Kedarnath shrines after their idols are carried from their respective winter abodes.

Apprehensions were being expressed in various quarters on presence of these priests during the portal opening ceremonies due to prevailing lockdown in the country to check the spread of novel Coronavirus (COVID-19) infection.

Due to the lockdown, the air, rail and road network in the country are totally jammed.

These apprehensions further gained ground after Prime Minister Narendra Modi announced extension of lockdown till May 3. Incidentally both Maharashtra and Kerala are the states where large numbers of COVID-19 affected patients are being reported.

On behalf of Uttarakhand government, the tourism and culture minister Satpal Maharaj talked with both these chief priests on Wednesday and assured them that necessary arrangements are being made for their travel to the State.

When contacted, the Rawal of Badrinath, Ishwari Prasad Namboodri said that he has quarantined himself at his home in Kerala. “The State Government has assured me that I would reach my destination in Uttarakhand before April 20,’’ he said.

The Rawal of the Kedarnath, Bhima Shankar Lingam also said that the Uttarakhand Government has informed him that necessary arrangement for his timely return to the State are being made.

Title: HC hears two PILs via video conferencing
Article:
In a first, the Uttarkahand High Court heard two public interest litigations via video conferencing. These two PILs were regarding the protection equipment provided to doctors and paramedical staff, and issues related to farmers considering the lockdown imposed for containment of the spread of COVID-19.

Hearing on the petition regarding protection equipment for doctors, other medical staff and other aspects of COVID-19 treatment, the division bench of justices Sudhanshu Dhulia and Ravindra Maithani has directed the government to submit a reply by April 18. Advocate Dushyant Mainali had filed the PIL seeking proper protective equipment for doctors and security arrangements for them. Raising questions at the safety of doctors and medical staff working on the frontline against COVID-19, the petitioner had contended that instead of PPE kits, the doctors and related staff were provided HIV kits which are not effective in protection from COVID-19.

The court has asked the Government to inform about the number of protective kits provided to doctors and medical staff, and measures taken for their security. The court has also asked if there is possibility of and whether the Government can set up laboratories for COVID-19 test in Udham Singh Nagar, Haridwar and Ramnagar. The government has also been directed to prepare guidelines for provision of telemedicine facilities in hospitals.

Hearing the second PIL regarding problems being faced by farmers due to the COVID-19 pandemic, the division bench asked the Central and State Governments what guidelines have been issued for harvesting of the Rabi crop.

The court has also asked if the State Government can facilitate the purchase of the Rabi harvest without crowding.

The court has sought a reply by April 18. Murli Manohar Srivastav had filed this PIL stating that the Rabi crop was ready to harvest but the harvest and sale was being affected by the lockdown.

Title: UT identified as hotspot, Admn to urge Centre to reconsider decision
Article:
The Union Territory of Chandigarh, which has reported 21 positive Covid-19 (Coronavirus) cases till Wednesday evening, has been included in the list of coronavirus hotspots released by the Central Government.

As per Centre’s guidelines, restrictions will continue to apply on hotspots or red zones till May 3. A district could move from the red to the green zone if it does not report any case for 28 days, and vice-versa.

The development has come as a major disappointment for the UT Administration, which has decided to approach the Central Government to reconsider its case and allow relaxations accordingly, after April 20.

The Prime Minister Narendra Modi had a day before announced that for the next one week till April 20, every town, district, state will be examined carefully and areas, which have shown improvement in tackling coronavirus will be given certain relaxations.

Following this, the Administration had already begun preparing a roadmap for allowing relaxations after April 20 in the city. Curfew was imposed in Chandigarh on March 24 to ensure social distancing and combat the spread of Coronavirus. The city has so far recorded 21 positive Coronavirus cases, out of which nine have already recovered and no death has been reported till Wednesday evening. While 1721 were put in home quarantine as a precautionary measure, 1226 have completed the quarantine period.

Manoj Parida, Adviser to UT Administrator while talking to The Pioneer said, “Chandigarh has been included in the list of 170 districts identified as Covid-19 hotspots or red zones released by Central Government.

“The Administration will approach the Central Government urging it reconsider Chandigarh’s case as more than nine persons have already recovered in the city. No coronavirus hotspots within the city have been identified,” he said.

“We were hoping to allow certain relaxations regarding public movement and opening of various establishments after April 20. But, no relaxations can be allowed in coronavirus hotspots as per Centre’s guidelines till May 3,” he added.

The UT Administrator VP Singh Badnore was also apprized about Centre’s decision to declare Chandigarh as a hotspot district, which requires strict restrictions in the city. The Administrator has directed the UT officers to ensure that the instructions received from Central Government be strictly implemented and supervised.

Notably, Chandigarh is a joint capital of Punjab and Haryana. While Punjab has so far reported 186 positive coronavirus cases, Haryana has recorded 190 cases.

The satellite township of Chandigarh namely Mohali in Punjab is also Covid-19 hotspot and has reported 56 cases, maximum in the State. Neighboring district of Panchkula in Haryana has reported six cases.

According to the Centre’s guidelines, in hotspots, containment zones will be demarcated by States/ UTs/ District administrations as per the guidelines of the Ministry of Health and Family Welfare. In these containment zones, the activities allowed for non-hotspots will not be permitted. There shall be strict perimeter control in the area of the containment zones to ensure that there is no unchecked inward or outward movement of population from these zones except for maintaining essential services (including medical emergencies and law and order related duties) and Government business continuity.

Title: MGNREGS allowed in State with riders
Article:
The State Government on Wednesday issued operational guidelines to be maintained during MGNREGS work in the State during the COVID-19 lockdown.

“All field officials working under the PD, DRDA, Executive Engineer, RWSS, BDO and GP level will attend their work normally in the field. The concerned head of office should also ensure full strength in the office which would provide necessary support to the field execution,” an official order said.

The concerned officials have been asked to ensure social distancing strictly in the field and contain the spread of coronavirus. No meetings would be organised, soap or hand wash and sufficient safe drinking water should be made available for sanitisation at the work site and informal gatherings of workers at a worksite should be avoided.

No sick person and persons above 60 years should be engaged in any work, stated the order.

Title: Punjab to use residential schools as isolation centres
Article:
Ramping up the health infrastructure and facilities, Punjab Government would use as many as 8,346 beds available in hostels of State’s all 10 residential meritorious schools as Covid Care Isolation Centres.

Informing this, the State Education Minister Vijay Inder Singla on Wednesday said that besides providing all State Government schools for the creation of isolation centres, the Department has also put 10 meritorious schools on the disposal of Deputy Commissioners to use them as Covid Care Isolation Centres.

Singla, who was reviewing the preparedness at Meritorious School Ghabdan (Sangrur), said that as many as 8346 beds are available in hostels of these residential meritorious schools and around 200 classrooms could also be used by the medical staff for various other purposes.

These schools are situated in Amritsar, Bathinda, Ferozepur, Gurdaspur, Jalandhar, Ludhiana, Patiala, Mohali, Sangrur and Hoshiarpur districts, said Singla.

Singla, who is also holding charge of PWD Minister, said that the Public Works Department’s officials have also been directed to fully cooperate with the local administration for any improvements required for setup of isolation or quarantine centres.

Title: 6 IAS officers to tackle Covid-19 in BBSR
Article:
The State Government has appointed six IAS officers for containment and prevention of COVID-19 in the Bhubaneswar Municipal Corporation (BMC) areas after the capital city has emerged as the epicentre of the virus spread in the State.

While ST and SC Development Secretary Ranjan Chopra and Energy Secretary Bishnupada Sethi have been assigned the north zone, Excise Secretary KK Lohani and Higher Education Secretary Saswat Mishra have been assigned the south-east zone.

Finance Secretary Ashok K Meena and Social Security and Empowerment of Persons with Disabilities (SSEPD) Commissioner-cum-Secretary Bhaskar Jyoti Sarma have been assigned the south west zone, stated a notification issued by Chief Secretary Asit Tripathy.

The move came after Chief Minister Naveen Patnaik reviewed the status of disease at a high-level meeting on Tuesday.

The concerned senior officers would be in overall charges of overseeing the containment and prevention activities including intensive sampling of primary and secondary contacts, contact tracing, household survey by the surveillance team in the containment zone and supply of essential commodities to the households under containment.

The officials would coordinate with the BMC or Commissioner of Police and other administrative departments working in the fight against COVID-19.

Title: Govt to issue appointment letters to doctors in waiting list: Anil Vij
Article:
To tackle the Covid-19 pandemic amid reports of shortage of doctors in some hospitals of the State, Haryana Health Minister Anil Vij on Wednesday said that the State Government has decided to issue fresh appointment letters to doctors on 116 posts, who were named in the waiting list.

“With the direction to join duty within 15 days of issuance of appointment letters, state Government had issued appointment letters to 312 selected doctors in March but only 196 of them have joined. A total of 116 have not joined duty and their joining date has expired. Now new appointment letters will be issued to those candidates who are in the waiting list,” Vij said.

The Health Minister said that this move is a part of mobilising all available resources in view of the Covid-19 crisis and to ensure the availability of doctors in rural parts of the State.

Sources in the health department said that the selection process of 447 doctors was initiated by the Health Department through Rohtak PGI. 312 doctors were selected and were offered to join their favorite district. A total of 1400 candidates had participated in the selection process done by PGI, Rohtak.

Despite Government’s consistent efforts, there has been shortage of doctors in the Government hospitals since long. Currently, there are 789 vacancies in the Government hospitals despite availability of about 2,500 doctors hospitals. If all 312 selected doctors join duty, there will still be a vacancy of 477 doctors in the State, officials said.

Meanwhile, Vij said that to provide medical services in rural areas, 211 medical teams have been formed to operate mobile clinics. These medical teams will visit different areas of the districts in Haryana Roadways buses, which will be converted into mobile clinics, to provide general OPD services and trace people exhibiting Covid-19 symptoms.

Talking to ‘The Pioneer’ over the phone, Vij said, “To address the regular medical issues of citizens left unaddressed due to the unfolding of the Covid-19 crisis, all district chief medical officers have been directed to form teams, consisting of doctors, paramedics and pharmacist, to operate mobile dispensaries.”

To execute this scheme effectively, all the DCs have been given necessary instruction and also directed to prepare the route plan of the mobile dispensary with the officials concerned. This dispensary will go to each village for the treatment of patients for at least two hours. Many villages will be covered in a day, the Minister added.

Vij said that to know the actual status on the execution of this scheme, he will review this scheme with DCs on Thursday.

The Health Minister said that instruction has been issued that social distancing will be taken care of once the mobile dispensary reaches the village. No crowd will be allowed to gather, he said, adding that the medical officers have been directed to send maintenance records of patients daily at State Headquarters. All Chief Medical Officers have been instructed to create routes by coordinating with the concerned DCs.

Sources in the Health department said that every mobile dispensary will have Allopathic, Urologist and homeopathic medicines. For mobile dispensaries to function, teams have been formed, which include doctors, paramedics and pharmacists. They will visit their assigned areas, examine the health condition of people who approach them for check-ups and provide them with medicine.

The time-table has been made for every village and mobile dispensary will visit the villages accordingly. To avail the service of mobile clinic, the villagers will be informed about when the mobile dispensary will reach their village. Once or twice in a week, a mobile dispensary will visit the village as per necessity.

Title: Naveen Patnaik is hero in corona battle
Article:
The unruly coronavirus has evoked the fear, precautionary spirit and frightful discussion among the human race as never before. The horrifically infective virus is the biggest enemy of mankind at the present. The entire human world is slowly coming together to destroy the invisible foe. The multifarious sovereign political entities that were at war for long have ignored hostilities and turned friends for survival.

Mighty and wealthy nations led by the USA are reeling under the pressure of helplessness as the virus is lurking everywhere irrespective of borders.

China believably discovered the virus first after taking a big beating. And since developed Western countries, having turned lazy due to riches, had dumped all their manufacturing activities in China to save money at enormous loss of employment, most of their nationals carried back the virus to their home locales. When Trump got to know about the pandemic, he was advised by his medical experts to let the country folks get infected to develop good enough ‘herd-immunity' and defeat the virus routinely. The previous SARS virus breakout in China was deadlier than corona but much less infective. The genetic material DNA of the previous one was less adaptive and so less lethal. Corona has the RNA genetic material which is way smarter in duping the host cell and getting itself ferociously multiplied. Incidentally, DNA is the master genetic material that stores and transmits the genetic code. The RNA is only the servant messenger to carry the message to newly-forming organism. The servant is always usually slier and bigger master of machinations. Corona is an RNA-virus that adapts hosts easily and jumps species immediately when in trouble.

By the time corona caused panic by assuming proportions of a global pandemic, huge damage was already done to those national communities that had intimate relationships of trade and other transactions with China. Around the close of February 2020 when India was groping in wilderness, Naveen Patnaik came heavily on the precaution mode having been guided perfectly by his chosen group of aides. Odisha, thus, is the first State to clamp the most critical lockdown technique as there was not much time in hand to persuade people to practise social distancing, constant hand-washing and more behavioural adaptations. PM Modi took cue and declared a nationwide lockdown. Naveen still scores by having established maximum number of COVID hospitals and installing the fastest testing equipment in Odisha.

The infection incidence and prevalence today across India are a bit misleading for the simple reason that ‘proportionate-to-population' tests are not being conducted due to lack of facilities. Odisha is one of fewest States to test huge numbers of COVID suspects. It is also the first State to extend the lockdown period to April-end. Naveen is smarter in disaster management. If Modi and Naveen join hands in nation-building efforts, wonders would happen.

Rightly, people have realised the greatest warriors in the ‘corona-destroy’ battle are low-wrung police functionaries that endure the scorching sun to keep public order intact; the nurses at hospitals who work in closest proximity with patients; the sanitary workers who keep clearing garbage from all around; and, lastly, the doctors some of whom are extremely dedicated in treating the afflicted people. Some doctors do shirk work out of fear of infection particularly those running private clinics. These cash-crazy crooks should be identified and brought to book. Besides, the bureaucratic administrators who are alert days and nights to ensure every official is delivering the desired service and everything is in place need to be hailed as heroes. People do not seem to know how top-level bureaucrats perform duties in nightmarish conditions because ultimately they would be blamed if things failed. But it is also true some tricky officials glorify themselves by confusing the media guys-in-a-hurry. They dramatise very ordinary acts during daily Press briefings.

Title: ‘Initiate action against those causing disruption in procurement’
Article:
Adopting a tough stand towards the people, who were threatening to disrupt the smooth arrangements made for wheat procurement, the Punjab Mandi Board on Wednesday issued directions to all the Secretaries of the Market Committees across the State to initiate strict action immediately against any person found causing hindrance in the procurement operations.

Punjab Mandi Board Secretary Ravi Bhagat said that it has come to their notice that a certain section of arhtiyas had threatened to boycott the procurement operations during Rabi Marketing Season 2020-21, which would not be tolerated at any cost.

He pointed out that the Mandi Board has already issued necessary directions to cancel the licenses of all such erring arhtiyas and warned them of further action under the strict provisions of the Disaster Management Act, 2005.

In order to ensure that farmers do not face any harassment, Bhagat further directed immediate cancellation of all farmers’ passes issued to those arhtiya threatening to go on strike and re-issuance of an equivalent number of these passes to other arhtiyas operating in the same mandi.

Bhagat clarified that as of now, there is no disruption of work in any Mandi across the State. However, arrivals are slow and nil in several mandis across the State.

Title: 25 Punjab cops selected for ‘DGP Honour for Exemplary Sewa to Society’
Article:
Punjab Director General of Police (DGP) Dinkar Gupta has selected 25 Punjab Police officers across districts for the coveted ‘Director General of Police Honour for Exemplary Sewa to Society’ for their exceptional community service on the frontlines of the Covid-19 operations and response activities in the State.

The awardees include four Superintendents of Police (SPs), one Assistant Superintendents of Police (ASP), one Deputy Superintendents of Police (DSP), six Inspectors, four Sub-Inspectors, three Assistant Sub-Inspectors (ASIs), two Head Constables and four Constables.

The award would honour those who have done outstanding work by going beyond the call of duty in various kinds of humanitarian activities during the current corona pandemic.

“They are selected from various nominations sent by the Commissioners of Police and Senior Superintendents of Police (SSPs) for the award introduced on the Chief Minister Capt Amarinder Singh’s initiative in the light of scale and sacrifice of over 45,000 policemen who are working relentlessly across the State along with social and religious organizations to realize the resolve that ‘no man will sleep hungry in Punjab’,” said the DGP Gupta.

Gupta said: “Nakodar ASP Vatsala Gupta did pioneering work in reaching out to the poor and underprivileged slum dwellers of Nakodar town, while Ropar DSP Varinder Jit Singh ensured supply of essential goods to the poor and needy by mobilizing volunteers. Ropar’s SI Jatin Kapoor motivated the Panchayats to impose a voluntary lockdown of their villages.”

Kharar Station House Officer (SHO) Bhagwant Singh proactively carried out the tracking and tracing of suspect coronavirus cases. Similarly, SBS Nagar SI Neeraj Chaudhary took the risk of visiting isolated corona patients to trace the contacts where the patients refused to cooperate with the epidemiologist and other doctors.

Pathankot SI Shohrat Mann is doing commendable work for the welfare of the people of Pathankot by providing food to the poor and the downtrodden. Fatehgarh Sahib SI Shakunt Chaudhary has also done commendable work as in-charge of a critical Naka point, said the DGP, giving details of the work done by some of the awardees.

Title: MCD completes sanitisation of all 100 wards
Article:
On the second day of its special sanitisation drive, the Municipal Corporation of Dehradun (MCD) sterilised 50 wards using over three lakh litre of disinfectant solution.

Earlier, on Tuesday, the MCD had sanitised 50 wards on Tuesday as a measure to prevent the spread of novel Coronavirus (COVID-19) in the city, the municipal corporation sanitised the remaining wards of the city on Wednesday.

The remaining 50 wards were divided into four zones and four nodal officers were appointed for each zone by municipal commissioner Vinay Shankar Pandey.

Using 40 spray machines and 60 tanks, the sanitation workers sprayed around 3.30 lakh litre of one percent hypochlorite solution in all the areas of remaining wards.

The work of sanitising the city was also inspected by Dehradun mayor Sunil Uniyal 'Gama' and the municipal commissioner.

In the past too, during the initial days of the lockdown the MCD had undertaken a three-day sanitation drive in which it sterilised all the wards of the city using more than two lakh litre of disinfectant solution.

According to deputy municipal commissioner Rohitash Sharma, the special sanitisation drive was undertaken as a precautionary measure in order to reduce the risk of the community spread of the novel coronavirus in Dehradun.

He said that such drives will be undertaken in the future too by the corporation.

Besides, the mayor also appealed people to remain indoors during the lockdown and advised them to contact the helpline numbers issued by the administration in case of emergencies.

Title: Cong demands return of stranded U’khandis
Article:
After the extension of the country wide lockdown by the Prime Minister Narendra Modi till May 3, the Uttarakhand unit of Congress party has intensified pressure on the State Government to make arrangement for return of Uttarakhandis stranded in other States.

Thousands of residents of the Uttarakhand working in other states are stranded and their hopes of return to homes got shattered when the Government extended the lockdown to control the spread of novel Coronavirus (COVID-19).

The Pradesh Congress Committee (PCC) Pritam Singh said that the State Government should make arrangements for return of these people of the State. “I appeal to the Chief Minister of State to show same empathy in ensuring return of people of state stranded in other areas and sending back the people of other states stuck here as shown in sending the stranded Gujarati’s back,’’ he said.

The Vice President of Uttarakhand Congress, Jot Singh Bisht said that the system which the State Government has set in place for return of Uttarakhandis stranded elsewhere has proved to be failure. “The officials concerned are either not picking up phones or are giving false assurances to the callers. The State

Government should prepare a plan for return of these stranded people of the State in a phased manner,’’ he said.

Bisht added that many of the stranded don’t have money to pay the rents of the houses they are living and are facing crisis of food also.

In a letter written to chief minister Trivendra Singh Rawat, Congress leader Manish Khanduri said that most of the youth of the State work in industrial areas or hotels and due to prevailing lockdown they have become unemployed.

He said that these people were somehow managing till April 14 but the extension of lockdown has brought them in a crisis.

Khanduri said that the State Government should make arrangement for return of these people.

Title: Wearing mask now mandatory in Bokaro
Article:
District administration, Bokaro has made it mandatory for people to wear masks in public places in a bid to check the spread of the novel coronavirus infection.

“I have issued orders with immediate effect. It is mandatory for every resident of the district, who is required to move out of the house due to urgent work, is required to wear a mask and comply with social distancing,” said Mukesh Kumar Deputy Commissioner Bokaro.
