He said that if any person is found outside wearing masks and violating social distancing, then strict legal action will be taken against them. “If the mask is not available, self-made masks or towel and handkerchiefs etc. can also be used,” added Kumar. “All the office bearers and police officers of the district and the heads of all other public sector undertakings and private companies are requested to ensure strict compliance in their establishments as well as in their areas even at their own level,” said the DC.

Appealing to masses to stay indoors and follow the lockdown strictly to prevent the spread of COVID-19, Kumar said people should venture out only in cases of emergency and to purchase essential commodities. “They should return home as soon as the purchase is done and not linger on roads,” he added.

“Police can now arrest anyone found outside without a good reason,” he said.

Anybody flouting the order will be warned by the police. However, the decision regarding levying penalty on violators is yet to be taken, said the official.

Those found violating the instructions will be punishable under disobedience to order duly promulgated by public servant of the IPC and the police authorities are empowered to take action against the violators, said an official.

Notably, Bokaro that has become coronavirus hotspots, witnessed a spike in the number of COVID-19 cases in the past few days and the total number of such cases rose to 9 and one death in the district till Tuesday.

A total of 133 reports has been received after investigation, out of which 124 cases are negative. There have been a total of 9 positive cases by adding one case on Tuesday, said AK Pathak Civil Surgeon Bokaro.

All of the patients who tested positive are having someway links with the religious gathering at the Markaz at Nizamuddin; either they have joined or having any kind of physical contact or link with such persons who have joined the religious gathering, he said.

Over 5347 people rushed from outside of the district are kept in-home quarantine. Though the administration identified over 300 people who rushed here from other different districts and were found hiding in their homes; all of them were sent to quarantine center, informed Pathak.

Title: Body of youth found hanging from tree in Dumka
Article:
Amidst ongoing lockdown in the city, body of a 20-year-old youth was found hanging from the branch of a tree in a forest cover behind Babhankheta village under Hansdiha police station area, 24 km from Dumka town on Wednesday morning.

The deceased was later identified as Rajkishor Mirdha.

The deceased had fair complexion and seemed to belong to a gentle family.

As the news spread, a police team reached the spot and got it down before sending it to the Dumka Medical College Hospital mortuary for post-mortem.

Officer-in-charge, Hansdiha police station, Amit Lakara said that they were investigating the incident and at present they could not say whether it is a case of suicide or a murder.

“We are yet to reach to a conclusion. From the inquest of the body we could not reach to a conclusion whether it is a case of suicide or a case of murder. Now only an autopsy report only can unfold the mystery behind the death of the Rajkishor,” said Mirdha.

The officer-in-charge said even if it is case of suicide which will come in the post-mortem report.

Title: Palamu DC’s letters to doctors, nursing homes yields results
Article:
Palamu DC’s letter to keep open clinics and nursing homes has begun to yield results faster than one has expected. Sources said DC in his letter has invoked para of the MHA which essentially deals with healthcare management in time of national disaster and pandemic.

Chief secretary Sukhdev Singh was equally apprised of the plights of the patients. Clinics and nursing homes have begun to open now. These were found closed since March 24 barring a few nursing homes and doctors who continued to serve.

Sources said on April 14 DC Palamu Shantanu Kumar Arahari issued a letter to doctors/ nursing homes management to start delivering medical assistance to patients maintaining their own safety protocol.

DC’s letter read that district administration was getting complaints with regard to the closure of clinics and nursing homes.

The tone and text of the DC’s letter is just a kind reminder to doctors and nursing homes management to come up and help the needy patients and with all safety gears for themselves.

It has a note of advice to doctors and nursing homes management that in the event of any patient coming to them with complaints of cold, cough fever & respiratory trouble be immediately referred to civil surgeon or to the nearest government health set up.

The shutdown of clinics and nursing homes in all these days made quacks to strike gold as for one intramuscular injection the charge went up from 20 rupees to 50 per injection while for intravenous injection one shot was worth 250 rupees.

Similarly saline transfusion which was 75 rupees per bottle was hiked to 150 rupees.

Sources said doctors and nursing homes here are fast opening their establishments.

IMA president Dr Arun Shukla said patients will have no problem as doctors and nursing homes are taking care of them.

Title: BSL accelerates sanitisation work
Article:
In order to prevent infection of Covid-19, Bokaro Steel Management is undertaking sanitization in the offices and departments inside and outside the plant including Bokaro General Hospital and various areas of the city on a war footing.

In this episode, the blast furnace, coke oven, sinter plant, SMS, RMHP, CRM, hot strip mill, slabbing mill and other departments, CISF pass section, plant main gate, steel gate, CISF barracks, canteen and welfare buildings inside the plant are constantly being sanitized. Apart from this, sanitization of BGH and various areas of the city is also being done continuously by teams of Fire Service Department and BSL Public Health Department as per protocol.

Similarly, the work of fogging in the township is also continuing. Apart from this, according to the guidelines received from the Central Zoo Authority in the Nehru park sanitization is being done as per rules by dry slaked lime and other disinfectants. Safety kits have been provided to all the employees of the park and special monitoring of animals is being done.

Title: Social organisation launches free vehicle disinfection drive
Article:
With the entire world fighting against Coronavirus, Zindagi Milegi Dobara Foundation has started an initiative of disinfecting the vehicles of the frontline workers, who are involved in fighting the pandemic. The movement, which was launched in the State capital on April 15 will be done free of cost for the Corona warriors.

The initiative launched on Wednesday at Panchwati Tower, Harmu Road, Ranchi by Zindagi Milega Dobara Foundation is being supported by Rajgarhia Ventures Private Limited.

The primary purpose of this movement is to serve the people involved in the battle on a daily basis and also to honour them. The free service is being provided to ambulances, district administration and municipal corporation vehicles, PCR’s and also to those from the print and electronic media.

“When everyone is sanitising their homes and offices, there is a possibility that Corona warriors might carry the virus in their vehicles. Disinfecting the vehicles will further curtail the spread of the same. This is also our way of encouraging and supporting them for their commendable work. It is also the first initiative of its kind which has been started espically for the warriors anywhere in India,” said Zindagi Milegi Dobara Foundation President Ashwini Rajgarhia.

The service will be available from 10 am to 6 pm at the venue and the warriors can avail it by showing their identity cards. A complimentary mask is also being given to the drivers.

“On the first day of this project as many as 28 vehicles which includes both two wheelers and four wheelers were sanitized. This movement will be carried on for as long as is required,” added Rajgarhia.

Title: Another Covid-19 case surfaces in Ranchi
Article:
Another Covid-19 suspect from Ranchi's Hindpiri locality tested positive on Wednesday, taking the total count of coronavirus cases in the State to 28, health officials said. At least 50 per cent of Jharkhand's Coronavirus cases are from Capital City Ranchi – all from Hindpiri, where the first case surfaced on March 31, they added.

"One suspect's samples tested positive for Covid-19 on Wednesday. He is around 35-year-old and a resident of Hindpiri," said Health Secretary Nitin Madan Kulkarni. The health department was looking for more details about the patient and how he may have got infected, Kulkarni added.

Out of the 28 cases in Jharkhand so far, 14 are from Ranchi, nine from Bokaro, two from Hazaribag and one each from Koderma, Giridih and Simdega, health officials said. A 22-year-old Malaysian woman, who attended the Tablighi Jamaat congregation in New Delhi and was apprehended from a Mosque in Hindpiri, was the first carrier of the virus in Jharkhand, sources said.

While the Government has sealed Hindpiri locality, which has emerged as a hotspot of the virus in Ranchi, at least six fresh cases of Covid-19 were reported from the locality in less than a week, health officials said. However, the Government's timely intervention has prevented the virus from spreading in other parts of the city, he added.

Despite a delayed entry in Jharkhand, the virus has infected 28 people in around a fortnight – a cause for concern for the health department here. While the Government is planning to abide by the latest guidelines of the Ministry of Home Affairs (MHA) for partial relief from the lockdown, it is likely to keep the affected areas of Jharkhand locked, sources said.

The virus has claimed two lives in the State so far – one each from Ranchi and Bokaro. Meanwhile, the Ranchi district administration is looking for a place where the bodies of Covid-19 victims can be buried. Locals have refused to allow burial of Covid-19 victims in residential areas.

The Ranchi District Administration has identified four secluded spots for burying the bodies of Covid-19 victims, officials said. However, the Government is yet to finalise one of the four spots, they added.

Title: Institutions & citizens contribute to CM relief fund
Article:
The Chief Minister relief fund has continued to receive contributions from various segments of society to assist in efforts against COVID-19. On Wednesday, the Unison group of educational institutions contributed a total of Rs 21 lakh to the relief fund. This amount includes Rs 11 lakh from the DIT University and Rs 5 lakh each from the IMS Unison university and Unison World School.

The group’s founding members Amit Agrawal and Anuj Agrawal presented the amounts in cheque to the Chief Minister Trivendra Singh Rawat.

The Unison group has distributed ration kits, hand sanitisers and other necessary items to the needy.

Under its corporate social responsibility, the Nainital Bank Limited has contributed Rs 11 lakh to the Uttarakhand State Disaster Management Authority (USDMA). Similarly, the chairman and managing director of Gunsola hydro power general private limited, Ratan Singh Gunsola contributed Rs 10 lakh to the CM relief fund by cheque presented to the CM.

Sanjiv Kumar Garg of SK Builders has contributed Rs 1.31 lakh to the relief fund. Concerned citizen Mona Bali contributed Rs 1lakh to the relief fund.

On behalf of SPECS, she also presented 100 PPE kits and 5,000 masks to the CM.

On behalf of Brahmakamal project, Deepak Rajput contributed Rs 1.58 lakh to the relief fund.

Hetram Mamgain, the husband of Rishikesh mayor Anita Mamgain and their son Himanshu contributed Rs 1 lakh and Rs 50,000 respectively to the relief fund.

Title: Administration gets tough on lockdown offenders
Article:
East Singhbhum district administration has gone tough to enforce lockdown in city and outskirts starting with declaration of second phase of lockdown till May 3.

East Singhbhum deputy commissioner Ravi Shankar Shukla and East Singhbhum senior superintendent of police, Anoop Birtharay have framed a new strategy where in the police forces have been advised to be more vigilant. Special focus is in areas like Sidhgora, Baridih, Agrico, Sakchi, Bistupur, Mango, Kadma, Telco, Burmamines, Jugsalai and Sonari.

“ We want people to understand the importance of lockdown. With the beginning of second phase of lockdown and in view of prohibitory order under Section 144 of the CrPC the focus is that people remain indoors,” said an official.

On Wednesday several offenders were nabbed during drive at Sakchi and Bistupur. Sensing the need of complete lockdown during second phase, the district administration has formed 19 surveillance teams for Jamshedpur, Mango, Jugsalai and 11 blocks of district.

The team is maintaining surveillance of the labourers and other residents for the quarantine period of 14 days and if anybody is found with symptoms would be kept under isolation at quarantine centers and their throat swab taken for sample test.

Meanwhile, traffic police jointly with city police could be seen vigilant at most of the commercial hubs seeking information from two-wheelers and four-wheelers about their reason for coming on the road.

Moreover, the administration has made it mandatory for everyone to wear mask (either three-layered or made of cloth) if they are outside their homes. And those violating this rule are being booked by police.

An official informed that if anyone found roaming without a mask will be booked under section 269 (negligent act likely to spread infection of disease dangerous to life), 270 (malignant act likely to spread infection of disease dangerous to life), 188 (disobedience to order duly promulgated by public servant) of IPC.

Title: High-level committee to tackle economic loss caused by lockdown
Article:
For bringing about improvement in the State’s economy and increasing livelihood resources, the State Government has formed a high level advisory committee with former chief secretary Indu Kumar Pande as its head. To reduce the loss caused the lockdown in place for preventing spread of COVID-19 and to strengthen the economy of the state, this high level committee has been formed on the directions of the chief minister Trivendra Singh Rawat.

While retired IAS officer Indu Kumar Pande has been made the chairman of this committee, its members will include industry principal secretary Manisha Panwar, finance secretary Sowjanya, finance additional secretary Bhupesh Tiwari and planning additional secretary Yogendra Yadav.

This committee will study the loss caused to the economy of the state due to the lockdown and given its recommendations to the State Government for improvement in economic resources. The committee will also consider which sectors to accord top priority to for facilitation of livelihood to the people.

This high level committee will present its report to the State Government at the earliest.

Title: Enough resources to provide food & ration to needy in US Nagar
Article:
The district administration of Udham Singh Nagar has distributed over two lakh cooked food packets since the implementation of lockdown in the State last month. The district administration is providing sufficient meals to those in need during the lockdown, especially labourers and daily wagers, according to district administration officials. As informed by the district’s Chief Development Officer (CDO) Mayur Dixit, about 20, 000 cooked food packets are being distributed in the district daily.

"Thousands of people are being provided meals by district administration on a daily basis. Though the distribution of food depends on the daily requirement of people, we generally distribute around 8000 to 10,000 dry ration kits daily in addition to around 20,000 cooked food packets," said Dixit. He added that the district administration has distributed over two lakh cooked food packets and about 45,000 dry ration kits so far.

The recipients of food packets and ration kits mainly include daily wagers and labourers who work in factories, a few senior citizens and the poor and destitute people, said Dixit.

He informed that meals are also provided to those who contact the administration through the helpline number. The CDO further informed that several local groups, Non Governmental Organisations (NGOs), and religious bodies like Gurudwaras are also helping the district administration in providing the meals to the needy.

The CDO also stated that the district administration has enough resources to provide ration and food to those in need during the extended lockdown till May 3.

Title: Saryu serves food to 83,150 persons
Article:
Jamshedpur East MLA Saryu Roy on Wednesday informed that a total of 83,150 persons have benefitted from foods and rations between March 27 and April 14 distributed from kitchen set up at his Bistupur residence for poor and needy affected during lockdown

Roy in line with government guidelines and with the cooperation of the district administration has opened a kitchen at his J Road residence in Bistupur to cater to lunch and dinner requirements of the poor and needy. The food packets containing puris, curry and pickles are being distributed by 10 volunteers in various localities of the township including Harijan Basti and Chuna Bhatta in Burmamines, Manifit Mandal Basti, Birsanagar Zones 3 & 7, Bagunnagar, Chhayanagar, Sakchi Leaf market, East Plant Basti, Kanchan Nagar, Namda Basti, Kailashnagar and other areas. On the first day, 1,500 packets of lunch and dinner were distributed.

The volunteers will distribute the packets individually as a measure of social distancing. The district administration has provided special passes to these 10 volunteers. The kitchen is being managed by the legislator’s nephew Asutosh Roy, social worker Ashok Goyal and Saryu Roy’s PA Ricky Kesri. Asutosh said that the business fraternity could lend its support by sending food items for the kitchen.

Title: Hotel & restaurant association does its bit amidst lockdown
Article:
The Nainital hotel and restaurant association head Dinesh Sah has stressed that the association is with the Government and is helping the needy through different means in these troubling times caused by the COVID-19 pandemic. The association has provided financial assistance to the Helping Hand group while the association’s members are also providing assistance in the personal capacity and will continue to do so for the people in Nainital if required in the future.

Shah said that tourism has experienced a drop during the past few years in lake city Nainital due to different reasons.

The global pandemic has affected all including the tourism industry.

Apart from being an important part of the state’s economy, the tourism industry also generates employment for a considerable number of people.

He said that tourism was one of the first businesses to be closed due to the COVID-19 pandemic and will open last after the situation returns to normal.

After resuming business too, the tourism industry is likely to take about six months to return to normalcy.

He expressed confidence that the Central and State Governments will take necessary measures considering the state of the tourism sector.

Title: Hussainabad MLA distributes 15,000 masks in constituency
Article:
Hussainabad MLA Kamlesh Kumar Singh has asked his partymen to distribute free masks among the people irrespective of socio economic status.

A senior NCP leader Binu Singh younger brother of MLA Kamlesh Kumar Singh said, “The Hussainabad MLA is all out to provide masks to people of his constituency. We are working in this direction day and night.”

Giving details Binu Singh said we have roped in one lady Anju Devi of Jamooney village who with the help of her trained girls are stitching 5,000 masks for our distribution.

Binu Singh said we are paying 2 rupees per mask, while we have provided the fabric for it.

He further said similar order for 5,000 masks has been placed with the central jail Daltonganj through the jail officials, where too inmates of the jail who have expertise on working on sewing machines are preparing masks at the same rate of 2 rupees per mask.

Similar preparation of masks numbering 5,000 is going on at Japla where one Guddu Singh has taken this responsibility of getting stitched masks @2 rupees per mask. Singh said, “Our first target is to distribute 15,000 masks work for which is in full swing at our three points.”

The MLA Kamlesh Kumar Singh’s family has offered his farm house called Baijnath Singh Sewa Ashram located on NH 75 to the administration to retain people with travel history for quarantine.

Binu Singh said our Ashram has a lot of space and the environment here is all healthy as despite it being on NH 75 it is too away from the noise of any traffic as already NH everywhere in the country has thin traffic these days.

He said he gave this offer to the administration in writing which was accepted as his Ashram is well furnished.

Ranjit Singh looks after the Ashram and now its inmates too besides government’s personnel.

He said Palamu administration has retained here three youths who came from Kota by car for a 14 day quarantine. Quoting doctorswho examined them Binu Singh said the Kota boys who hail from Daltonganj are in a very good health. One of the Kota boys undergoing quarantine said it took them 22 hours to reach Daltonganj by car from Kota and knowing that they would not find food on NH they had with them lots of ready to eat food and fruits and again lots of water.

Title: CM seeks equipment for more tests in State
Article:
Chief Minister Hemant Soren today said that he has talked to Union Health Minister Dr Harsh Vardhan and has requested to ensure availability of labs and test kits so that more tests could be conducted in the State and doctors can conduct tests swiftly across the State. The CM, while talking to media persons here on Wednesday said that the State Government will take decision on the guidelines of the Union government after assessing its practicality.

The CM said that in the wake of Coronavirus infection and lockdown, providing food to poor and helpless by institutions across the State is commendable. “Today, in order to provide food by the Prajapati community, we went to Shaheed Maidan. Food is being provided to hundreds of people every day. Everyone should think of providing help to the needy under adverse circumstances,” he said.

Soren said that more than 5,000 Didi kitchens, kitchens are operated in police stations, Dal Bhat Yojana and self-help institutions are getting sufficient food for needy in Jharkhand. “Necessary help is being provided to every Jharkhand resident stuck in lockdown outside the State. Millions of people across the State are getting free food. Efforts are on to provide free dry ration and hot food to about seven lakh people stranded in various states. You have complete trust in your government. Never pay attention to rumours. None of us have seen such a disaster before. Despite this, the present government is doing everything necessary to keep the people of the state safe and secure,” he said.

In response to a question, the CM said that mischievous elements act to incite religious sentiments. Such people do not even see the circumstances. The government has an eye on them. The government will deal with them strictly, he said.

Title: Delhi riots: Court sends Jamia student to 14-day judicial custody
Article:
A Delhi court Wednesday sent a student of Jamia Millia Islamia, arrested for allegedly hatching a conspiracy to incite communal riots in North-east Delhi, to judicial custody for 14 days, said his lawyer.

Metropolitan Magistrate Rohit Guliya sent Meeran Haider (35), PhD student and the president of RJD youth wing's Delhi unit, to judicial custody after the expiry of his police remand in the case related to the communal violence in northeast Delhi in February over the Citizenship (Amendment) Act, his advocate Akram Khan said.

The court had earlier sent him to the custody for nine days after the police said it was needed to unearth a larger conspiracy in the case.

Rajya Sabha MP and RJD leader Manoj Jha had tweeted, "Delhi Police called him for investigation and then received orders from above and arrested Meeran Haider, who has been helping people during the time of coronavirus outbreak."

The Jamia Coordination Committee (JCC), a group comprising students and alumni from the varsity, had condemned the arrest and demanded his immediate release.

"The country is facing a massive health crisis, however, the state machinery is busy harassing and framing student activists in false cases to suppress voices of dissent," they said. The JCC said Haider was diligently working to provide ration to the needy during the lockdown.

Communal clashes had broken out in northeast Delhi on February 24 after violence between the Citizenship law supporters and protesters spiralled out of control leaving at least 53 people dead and around 200 injured.

Title: 3,473 people detained for violating lockdown
Article:
The Delhi Police on Wednesday registered over 200 cases and detained 3,473 people in Delhi for violating government orders during the coronavirus lockdown.

According to the data shared by the police, 244 cases were registered under section 188 (for disobedience to order duly promulgated by public servant) of the Indian Penal Code till 5pm.

A total of 3,473 people have been detained under section 65 (persons bound to comply with reasonable directions of police officers) and 382 vehicles have been impounded under section 66 of the Delhi Police Act, they stated.

A total of 801 movement passes have been issued, police said.

Total 79 cases were registered against people for stepping out of their houses without wearing masks.

Since March 24, a total of 84,030 people have been detained so far for violating order under section 65 of the Delhi Police Act.

Title: Ambulance driver held for ferrying 9 passengers for Rs 16K in Vasant Kunj
Article:
Amid the countrywide lockdown due to the Covid-19, the Delhi Police on Wednesday intercepted an ambulance in South Delhi's Vasant Kunj area in which nine people were travelling. Police said that the ambulance of the Uttar Pradesh number was caught from NH-8 on Wednesday afternoon.

According to police, the driver, identified as Krishan Kumar, has picked eight people from Manesar in Haryana.

"All the nine people, including the driver, are the residents of Bast district in Uttar Pradesh. There was a deal that Kumar would pick these eight people from Manesar in Haryana and drop them to Basti. The deal was fixed at Rs 16,000," said a senior police official.

"When they reached Vasant Kunj area, police checked the ambulance and found no patient inside it. A case is being registered under relevant sections of the Indian Penal Code (IPC) against the driver," said the senior police official adding that the eight people were sent to Mahipalpur shelter home. "After the lockdown several reports came which stated that some people are using Ambulance for transporting vehicles across the border following which police has strengthen its vigil on bordering areas and continuous checking of Ambulances is going on," said the senior police official.

Title: 3 hotspots declared virus free in G’gram
Article:
In a welcome news in the nationwide fight against the coronavirus epidemic, three containment zones in Gurugram have been declared to be free of the deadly disease. Gurugram District Collector and Deputy Commissioner Amit Khatri issued a new order of containment areas on the recommendation of District Disaster Management Committee and Containment Review Committee on Wednesday.

In the orders issued by the Collector, 6 zones of Gurugram district have been declared as containment zones, whereas earlier 9 areas of the district were containment zones.

According to the orders issued by the District Collector, 3 areas of Gurugram are no longer in the containment zone category. These include Nirvana Country in sector-54, Palam Vihar, Labernam Society in Sushant Lok-1 and Emaar Palms in sector-83.

Title: Migrant labourers residing in Yamuna riverbed shifted
Article:
Days after several media reports highlighted the plight of the migrant labourers residing in the Yamua river bed near the Kashmere Gate bus terminal, the Delhi Government on Wednesday finally asked the Delhi Police to get the area vacated and take the migrants to a shelter home.

The Delhi Police on Wednesdaay reached the Kashmere Gate area with buses to relocate the migrant labourers, who were residing in the Yamuna riverbed just below the flyover that connects east Delhi's Geeta Colony with the Kashmere Gate Inter State Bus Terminal (ISBT).

Over 2,000 migrant labourers were forced to stay on the riverbed were living in pathetic situation with no facilities of drinking water and toilets. They got food during the day and night when it arrived at the nearby night shelters.

The Yamuna riverbed where these migrant labourers were staying for more than 10 days is just two kilometres away from the residence of Delhi Chief Minister Arvind Kejriwal and Lt Governor Anil Baijal.

Title: School kids help people fight virus
Article:
While the country is fighting with life-threatening coronavirus, school children are coming with informative ideas to raise awareness among students. In a similar attempt, Divyanshi, a student of Sanskriti School who is also a classical dancer, keeps motivating people and friends about the ways to combat with the pandemic by adopting some of the practices suggested by the Government agencies and medical experts.

“At the time when world is grappling with possibly the worst public health crisis that forced the Governments to impose countrywide lockdowns in India to contain the spread of the Coronavirus, one need to be stay inside and follow guidelines issued by the various agencies,” she said.

Divyanshi also suggested ways to tackle the situation. “Staying indoors, frequently washing hands, sanitising phone covers and other things, practicing social distancing etc are some of the measures to avoid catching infection,” she said.

In order to combat with mental health issues, she said one should keep himself busy in reading books, writing, watching movie, doing meditation etc.

Title: Pvt hospitals start yoga sessions to fight anxiety
Article:
To tackle loneliness, anxiety and stress amid nationwide lockdown, private hospitals in the national Capital started yoga sessions and video consultation facilities especially for women and children to help them face the challenges.

With strict restrictions on movement and safety concerns forcing people to stay at home, those who needed medical care are also finding it hard to access a doctor. In order to address these concerns, ‘Rainbow Children’s Hospital & Birth Right’ has thrown open video consultation facilities to help women and children seek medical advice for Gynaecological and Paediatric issues sitting at homes.

Similarly, to help such women, leading mother and child care hospitals have launched virtual LAMAZE (information-based classes for childbirth preparation and breastfeeding) and prenatal yoga classes for their regular as well as new patients.

The development comes a few days after the Ministry of Health and Family Welfare issued guidelines on the practice of telemedicine, giving much-needed statutory cover to health practitioners offering remote are in India.

Dr Shilpi Srivastava, lactation expert at Motherhood Hospital (Noida) said that she has personally monitored the ultrasound reports and doctor's consent of each patient before letting them be a part of the virtual class in hour-long session. “I am teaching basic yoga asanas like pranayam (breathing exercise), bridging pose, clam pose, cat and cow pose and child pose which are highly beneficial during pregnancy,” she said.

“Yoga not only offers great flexibility when it comes to indoor exercise options, but also helps to keep the stress and anxiety away. It also boosts your immune system functions a lot better,” Dr Srivastava said.

“Technology has given us viable alternatives to address the medical concerns of a number of patients remotely though video consultations. Our Doctors will continue to provide video consultations to as many patients as possible until the outbreak is controlled. Only patients with a healthcare emergency need to visit the hospital,” said Dr Ramesh Kancharla Chairman of ‘Rainbow Children’s Hospital & Birth Right’.

Title: Govt plans dedicated mortuaries, cremation land
Article:
The State Government is planning to come up with dedicated mortuaries and cremation land following protest over burial of the body of a patient who died due to coronavirus infection at Ranchi.

According to information, the Cabinet sub-committee formed to monitor plans to meet the challenges association with the Covid-19 pandemic will discuss the formation of dedicated mortuaries and cremation land for Covid-19 death cases.

State Health Minister, Banna Gupta who has been given the responsibility for coordination of the sub-committee said that the first meeting would be held on Thursday at State secretariat in Nepal House and a final decision on setting up of dedicated mortuaries and cremation land for Covid-19 death cases amongst other issues will be taken.

“We have come to know about the protest at Ratu graveyard from local residents over burial of a Covid-19 positive patient. We discussed at the Cabinet meeting on Tuesday. We are planning of setting up special mortuaries in at least dedicated Covid-19 hospitals across the state for Covid-19 death cases.

This apart, we are also planning to identify lands far away from inhabited areas for cremation/burial of Covid-19 patients. However, the final decision would be taken by the sub-committee in its meeting on Thursday,” said Gupta.

Significantly, the cabinet sub-committee comprises state finance minister Rameshwar Oraon, State labour minister Satyanand Bhokta, State transport minister Champai Soren and Banna Gupta.

“We need to understand the sentiments of public. We do not want to build confidence of public after the death of a Covid-19 patient. It was disheartening to read from papers that the dead body of the Covid-19 patient in Ranchi was kept for hours in an ambulance instead of a mortuary. We want to have such special mortuaries in at least Covid-19 dedicated hospitals which would be at a small distance from the regular mortuary to avoid any controversies amongst masses,” suggested Gupta.

Gupta has also formed a five-member Covid-19 assistance committee and released their mobile number for any assistance on Covid-19 issues 24x7. The committee is functioning from the MGM Hospital at Sakchi.

Gupta said that the Government is keeping an eye on the spread of the virus and proactive measures are being taken to control the situation.

He went on to add that the situation is better in the state. The committee will help in any type assistance required to fight the virus. People can contact the committee members required for the assistance. The committee will also lend its support to the health department.

It may be mentioned here that as of now MGM Medical College testing unit can test a maximum of 40 samples daily while RIMS in Ranchi can accommodate 90 in a day.

Title: Chandigarh to name and shame curfew violators
Article:
UT Adviser Manoj Parida said that he has sought a list from Chandigarh Police regarding the curfew violators. The list would be published on social media to name and shame curfew violators, he said. List of VIPs, who are violating the curfew restrictions has been sought from the Police. It is unfortunate that people are still going for morning and evening walks, defying curfew order in the city, Parida added.

Notably, the UT Police had on Monday rounded up 466 morning walkers in various parks across Chandigarh in a special drive. From March 23 (midnight) till Wednesday evening, a total of 13954 persons have been rounded up for violating curfew orders in the city. A total of 6928 vehicles have been detained, out of which 4219 were impounded.

Action has been taken against 347 persons under Section 188 (Disobedience to order duly promulgated by public servant) and other sections of IPC. FIRs have been registered against 95 people for not wearing face masks at public places in the city.

Title: Lower courts to work for 1 hour from April 20
Article:
All the sub-ordinate courts of the State and their offices shall function for an hour daily from April 20, said an order passed by the Registrar General of Orissa High Court here on Wednesday.

The order, copies of which were forwarded to the entire district and sessions judges, chairman of Odisha State Bar Council and to the Advocate General, among others, said that this step was taken in the wake of the Government of India’s decision to extend the nationwide lockdown to May 3.

“The courts and their offices where there will be morning sittings shall function from 9 am to 10 am; and other places, where there will be no morning sittings; the courts and their offices will function from 11 am to 12 noon,” the order of the High Court Registry said.

The order also said that this temporary arrangement for the limited functioning of the lower courts would be made from April 20 until further orders.

Title: 3-year-old donates ` 5,500 to CM fund
Article:
A three-year-old girl has donated a sum of Rs 5,500 to the Chief Minister’s Relief Fund (CMRF) to spend the money for State’s fight against COVID-19.

She is Snehashree alias Khushi, daughter of Ranjan Kumar Mallick of Balabhdrapur village under Pattamundai block.

Khushi brought her piggy bank and told her mother to donate the money after she came to know from the family members that the country is fighting against the coronavirus pandemic, for which they were not going to celebrate her birthday in a big way.

“It really surprised us when we heard such words from our little daughter," said Ranjan.

Title: Monsoon to be delayed in State
Article:
Even as the mercury soared to above 40 degree Celsius in different parts of Odisha on Wednesday, the Indian Metrological Department (IMD) predicated that the arrival of southwest monsoon is likely to be delayed in the State.

Union Ministry of Earth Sciences Secretary Madhavan Nair Rajeevan said, “The onset of southwest Monsoon is likely to be delayed by three to four days in case of Odisha. Instead of its normal date of arrival on June 9 or 10, the monsoon may touch the State on June 13.”

Meanwhile, the Regional Office of IMD here predicted that partly cloudy sky with thunder and lightning is likely in Bhubaneswar and neighbourhood on Thursday.

While issuing a yellow warning, the weather office predicted that thunderstorm with lightning is very likely to occur at one or two places in Khordha Subarnapur, Angul, Keonjhar, Mayurbhanj, Dhenkanal, Baleswar and Bhadrak districts till 8.30 am on Thursday.

Title: Get free online medical consultation
Article:
For the people of Delhi, appointment and consultation with doctors is just a click away during the ongoing lockdown period as the Delhi Government on Wednesday joined hands with ‘CallDoc’ app developers offering free online medical consultation to reduce the spread of Covid -19.

With 100 plus doctors on board, the app Calldoc has been designed for 24X7 free online medical consultation services in Delhi to help patients connecting doctors via simple click for their non - emergency medical needs.

Through this, patients can easily consult with General Physicians as well as Specialists from home at any time convenient to them. This will save the trouble of physical travel for regular OPD visits, especially to senior citizens. 100+ doctors from Delhi are offering their services for free via this App.

CallDoc is a cloud-based platform created by Oncall Medicare Pvt. Ltd. to provide citizens with better and faster healthcare at any time and place of their convenience.

Health Minister Satyendar Jain said, “Delhi government is glad to collaborate with CallDoc app to bring 24x7 online medical consultations for free to the people of Delhi. This will save the trouble of physical travel for regular OPD visits, especially to senior citizens. We are proud of the 100+ doctors from Delhi who are offering their services for free via this App.”

The outbreak of Covid-19 has put lot of pressure on the healthcare infrastructure of all states, including Delhi. Delhi government is working round the clock to ensure that all citizens medical needs are supported. It is likely that the outbreak of this virus has made it difficult for people to visit hospitals and doctors, on non-emergency medical issues. The CallDoc app will help people in such situations, while at the same time reducing the chances of transmission at hospitals and clinics.

CallDoc is a cloud-based platform created by Oncall Medicare Pvt. Ltd. to provide citizens with better and faster healthcare at any time and place of their convenience.

The user is able to connect to Doctor on Video /Audio/Chat and get the consultation on phone by using this mobile app. It saves time that is spent in the waiting room and allows patients to consult leading doctors and avail instant treatment for non-emergency conditions.

Through the App, patients can upload their test reports for Doctor’s review and Doctors can upload prescriptions after consultation. “

Over 100 doctors have been onboarded by Delhi Government on the CallDoc app who will provide free and hassle-free consultations to any patient.

“These comprise of doctors affiliated to Delhi Medical Council, as well as doctors from Delhi government’s University College of Medical Sciences (UCMS) and Maulana Azad Medical College (MAMC),” Delhi government said.

Arun Dagar, Founder and Chief Executive CallDoc app said, “That at these times when the world has been swept away by the pandemic, it becomes our solemn duty to make sure that we as a community can overcome the obstacles by joining hands and forging partnerships. We at Oncall Medicare are extremely pleased with collaboration with the Government of NCT, Delhi, and that we are able to serve those in need in this manner. Our services , along with the well laid network of the Government of NCT, Delhi will be able to deliver affirmative outcomes and provide relief to the people at large and all the stakeholders.”

Title: Tablighi chief booked for culpable homicide
Article:
The Delhi police on Wednesday booked the Nizamuddin Markaz chief Maulana Saad and others under culpable homicide not amounting to murder after attendees died of coronavirus. Police said that 'lookout notice' has been issued against 1,900 foreign Tabhlighi Jamat attendees who had attended the congregation at Nizamuddin Markaz in March.

Tablighi Jamaat's supreme leader, Maulana Saad had organised the religious gathering at Nizamuddin Markaz last month against the social distancing protocol imposed by the Centre Goverment at that time to curb the spread of the coronavirus.

A First Information Report (FIR) was registered against the cleric on March 31 at Crime Branch police station on a complaint of the Station House Officer of Nizamuddin. He was earlier booked for holding the event, police said.

"After several attendees of the Tablighi Jamaat event succumbed to coronavirus, police added section 304 (culpable homicide not amounting to murder) of the Indian Penal Code (IPC) in the FIR against the leader," said a police official.

"Some foreigners who attended the event have also been booked for violation of visa norms," he said.

In an audio message, Kandhalvi had said that he was exercising self-quarantine after several hundreds who visited the Tablighi Jamaat congregation at Nizamudddin Markaz tested positive for coronavirus.

The FIR registered against the Tablighi Jamaat event says that the Delhi Police contacted the authorities of Nizamuddin Markaz on March 21 and reminded them of the government order which prohibited any political or religious gathering of more than 50 people.

"Despite repeated efforts, the event organisers failed to inform the health department or any other Government agency about the huge gathering inside the Markaz and deliberately disobeyed government orders," the FIR stated.

"The sub district magistrate of Defence Colony inspected the premises several times and found that around 1,300 people, including foreign nationals, were residing there without maintaining social distance. It was also found that there were no arrangements of hand sanitizers and face masks," the FIR adds.

The Nizamudddin centre, attended by thousands, turned out to be a hotspot for spread of coronavirus not only in the national capital, but the entire country. More than 25,500 Tablighi members and their contacts have been quarantined in the country after the Centre and the state governments conducted a mega operation to identify them.

Title: Food distributed to cops at Kapashera
Article:
The President of Police Families Welfare Society (PFWS), Pratima Shrivastava, on Wednesday distributed food and essentials to police personnel in South-West Delhi's Kapashera police station.

"The police personnel of police station, along with outside Central Armed Police Force (CAPF) personnal, were provided nutritious lunch packs, a set of soaps, both for personal hygiene and washing, sanitisers and mask, rejuvenating drink and chocolate /Chunky Bars," said Asif Mohammed, the Deputy Commissioner of Police (DCP), licensing.

"This was a recognition of hard work and professional commitment shown by the entire Delhi Force which stands united in the fight against COVID 19 pandemic. The responsibility of Delhi police in ensuring the right balance between ensuring complete lockdown as mandated by central government and maintaining essential supplies and assisting the citizens at large in emergency services has been well appreciated," the DCP added.

"Nearly 1000 packets among the most needy migrant labourers living in the area near Mansa Ram Public School and Church Wali Gali near Appu Ghar, in the jurisdiction of Kapashera area. They were also given additional bathing and washing soaps for hygiene purpose. The entire distribution programme was undertaken with observing social distancing norms and other precautions," said the DCP.

Title: Call cops to PHQ only when absolutely necessary: DGP
Article:
State director general of police (DGP) DM Awasthi on Wednesday instructed senior police officials to call police personnel to the police headquarters (PHQ) only when it is absolutely necessary.

They will continue to work from home until May 3, the DGP said.

In the view of the lockdown being extended until May 3, the DGP has directed senior officials to avoid unnecessary calling police personnel and other employees to the PHQ.

As per the order issued by DGP, all additional director generals of police and other senior police officials have been asked to complete important work with the help of their personal staff.

They have been directed to come to their office only if it is absolutely necessary. Police officials have been instructed to keep their mobile phone on.

The units in the PHQ, which require mandatory presence of officials and other employees, have been directed to ensure either minimum presence or allocation of duty in shifts.

Those directed to reach the office, are requested to reach their workplace avoiding public transport or crowded places.

The police officials and other employees have been requested to reach their office in personal vehicles.

As a preventive measure, the officials and employees have been asked to wear masks and sanitise their hands before entering the office.

During working hours, all the employees will have to keep their face covered with masks and sanitise their hands with hand-wash, soap and water or sanitizer.

To check further spread of the deadly Covid-19, the DGP has directed all superintendents of police to suspend all ongoing training programmes with immediate effect.

Title: LoP slams Baghel for govt’s failure to procure paddy at MSP
Article:
Leader of Opposition and senior BJP leader Dharamlal Kaushik, in a letter drew the attention of chief minister Bhupesh Baghel about his government’s failure to procure paddy from farmers as announced in the assembly.

In the letter, Kaushik said as per the announcement made during in House, the state government had decided to procure paddy at the minimum support price from farmers of the state and issued them token to sell their produce.

But until now, the government has failed to procure paddy from farmers at the minimum support price, the BJP leader said.

Blaming state officials, Kaushik said the announcement till date has not been implemented.

Pointing out problems being faced by farmers, the BJP leader said, he has been receiving calls from farmers to intervene as they were facing economic crises during the lockdown, which has now been extended until May 3.

Letter urges the chief minister to intervene in the matter and direct the officials to procure the paddy from farmers who have been issued token until February 19.

Title: CM directs WRD to release water for daily use in villages
Article:
Chief Minister Bhupesh Baghel on Wednesday directed the state water resources department to release water from reservoirs to fill village ponds, keeping in view of coming summer months and to ensure that villagers have access to water for their daily use.

With the arrival of summer, the village ponds dry up causing acute water shortages in villages, every year.

The CM has directed the state water resources department, to release water for reservoirs in the state as the temperature is increasing every day, and there is a shortage of water in the ponds for daily use in many rural areas.

Like every year, the process of releasing water from reservoirs to ponds should be started immediately to overcome the problem in rural areas, he said.

The CM directed the department officials that special care should also be taken to ensure there is no wastage of water during the summer months.

He has asked officials to make necessary arrangements to fill ponds used for irrigation by following all precautions and safety instructions, including social distancing to prevent the spread of coronavirus, keeping in mind the current circumstances during the lockdown.

Title: ‘Fatafat-easy home delivery' app launched by BMC
Article:
The district authorities in Bilaspur have launched a mobile application for doorstep delivery of essential commodities and every-day use goods during the Covid-19 lockdown, a senior civic official said on Tuesday.

Bilaspur municipal commissioner Prabhakar Pandey said the service was aimed at ensuring that people remain indoors during the lockdown, which has been extended until May 3.

'Fatafat - easy home delivery' app, which was launched on Monday, was already receiving a good response in Bilaspur town, he said.

The district administration and the civic body created the app in collaboration with a software company.

Citizens can download the app on their smartphones and order groceries, medicines and dairy products from shops of their choice in their vicinity, Pandey said, adding that a ward-wise list of shops will be available on the platform.

Shopkeepers will have to arrange for home delivery, but in case they need help, volunteers appointed by the municipal corporation would be deployed for the purpose, he said.

Orders can be placed on the app between 8 am and 10 am and deliveries will be made until 2 pm on the same day, while orders placed after 10 am will be delivered by 12 noon the next day, the senior official said.

Both cash-on-delivery and online payment options are available on the app and no extra charges are levied for home delivery, he added.

The application will benefit many during the lockdown, especially senior citizens who live alone, the official said.

Title: Union cabinet secretary speaks to state officials on Covid-19
Article:
Union cabinet secretary Rajiv Gauba on Wednesday reviewed in detail the lockdown and the measures being taken for prevention and control of Covid-19 infection, in a video conference with chief secretaries, home secretaries, industry secretaries and DGPs of all the states.

Chhattisgarh chief secretary RP Mandal, additional chief secretary (home) Subrat Sahoo, principal secretary (commerce and Industry) Manoj Pingua, health secretary Niharika Barik Singh and other officials attended it.

Mandal informed the Union cabinet secretary that in Chhattisgarh, 4,933 people have been tested for Covid-19, out of which 33 were found positive, which is the lowest number of Covid-19 positive cases diagnosed in the entire country.

Twenty-three out of the 28 districts in the state have no patients of Covid-19, he said.

The chief secretary said that Covid-19 dedicated, well-equipped hospitals or facilities with a total of 1,700 bed-capacities are ready. Besides, adequate numbers of rapid testing kits, personal protective equipment (PPE) kits and other essential goods are available in the state.

The Union cabinet secretary gave instructions to examine and identify work that can be done while keeping physical distance by April 20.

In rural areas, MNREGA work, water conservation, road construction, pond-related work among others can be done while keeping physical distance and employment can be provided in the rural areas.

Besides, industries can resume production if they have proper food, and accommodation facilities for the workers within the premises of the industrial areas, the Union cabinet secretary said.

Inter-state transport will not be resumed as of now, the central official said, and added that the need for strict implementing of the lockdown in infection hotspots is must.

Besides, the state government can decide on agricultural work, rural development work and other employment-oriented work in the rural areas until April 20.

Title: Nursing staff of AIIMS looks after Covid-19 patient’s two toddlers
Article:
Proving to be Good Samaritans, the nursing staff at the All India Institute of Medical Sciences (AIIMS) Raipur, have come forward to take care of two toddlers of a woman, who has tested positive for COVID-19 and is being treated at the hospital.

Official source in AIIMS said the children—one, a 3-month old and the other, a 22-month old—who were with their mother, have, however, tested negative for the virus.

Earlier, a maternal uncle of the children was called by the AIIMS authorities, but as soon as he reached Raipur, his test report for the Covid-19, turned out to be positive, the official said.

Later, the woman’s mother was called to look after the children, but on Wednesday, she too tested positive for Covid-19.

Considering the situation of the family, the nursing staff at the premier hospital, themselves have came forward and are now looking after the two toddlers till further arrangement is made.

Title: ‘Coronavirus: C’garh to start pool testing’
Article:
Pushing for increased screening of Covid-19, the state health authorities are all set to carry out pool testing.

The health minister TS Singhdeo in a tweet said that the department was ready to start the testing in at least one lab in the state.

“In order to effectively us the extended lockdown period, I have initiated measurers to start pool testing, in at least one of our labs, at the earliest”, Singhdeo tweeted.

Notable, a pool test is done for an area that is lesser prone to the disease to get a “realistic estimation” of the spread of the disease.

The testing increases the screening capacity to manifold and helps assessing the spread of disease well within the desired time.

Similarly, the health department also decided to use tuberculosis testing machine for detecting coronavirus infection.

Singhdeo, in statement further said that though it takes three hours to test for the infection, the available apparatus will enhance the testing capacity.

“The test will be done at the TB hospital, Lalpur and later on will be extended to all the district hospitals where the testing apparatuses are available,” he said.

Title: Rlys to supply 30K PPEs to docs by April-end
Article:
In order to meet growing demand for personal protective equipment (PPE), the Indian Railways on Wednesday said that it plans to supply 30,000 PPE to medical professionals by April-end and 1,00,000 till May, 2020.

The prototype coveralls have already cleared the prescribed tests with the highest grades at the authorised ‘Defence Research and Development Organisation’ (DRDO) laboratory at Gwalior, the ministry said in a statement.

“Doctors, medical professionals, other health workers and care-givers of the Indian Railways are working tirelessly to fight the Covid-19 disease. All these personnel are directly exposed to the Covid-19 disease when working amongst infected patients. As a first line of defence against contracting the novel coronavirus, they need to be provided with a special kind of impervious coverall that acts as a barrier to the virus as well as other disease carrying fluids,” it said.

In order to fill the gap in availability and requirements of PPEs, Jagadhari workshop of Northern Railway had taken the initiative to design and manufacture a prototype PPE coverall, it said, adding that the prototype coverall was tested by ‘Defence Research Development Establishment Laboratory’ of DRDO at Gwalior, authorised for conducting such tests.

“Since each such coverall can only be used once they are required in very large numbers. As the incidence of Covid-19 disease increases, even though in a relatively controlled manner, the requirement of PPE coveralls is also multiplying,” it said.

Taking this initiative forward, Indian Railways has been able to procure and distribute to its workshops and other units sufficient raw material for manufacturing more than 30,000 PPE coveralls in the current month (April 2020).

The Ministry said that it has set the target of manufacturing another 1,00,000 PPE coveralls in the month of May, 2020, and sourcing of appropriate raw material has been started.

“All this has been done despite there being a major global shortage of appropriate raw material as well as machinery for manufacturing PPE coveralls. Behind this endeavour is the time-tested capability of Indian Railway’s workshops and production units of manufacturing and maintaining some of the safest railway rolling stock in the world,” it said.

The same capabilities, expertise, protocols and procedures usually followed for design, manufacturing and use of rolling stock, have been utilised for enabling field units and workshops to start manufacturing high quality PPE coveralls so rapidly, it said.

It is worthwhile to note that the same dedication has already seen Indian Railways converting more than 5000 of its passenger coaches into mobile quarantine and isolation facilities in a very short period.

Title: Rlys earns Rs 7.5 cr in lockdown
Article:
The Indian Railways (IR) has earned Rs 7.54 crore by transporting 20,400 tonnes essential items during the 21-day lockdown.

A senior Railway Ministry official said that transportation of essential items like medical supplies, medical equipment, food, etc in small parcel sizes is going to be very important during the lockdown in the wake of Covid-19. In order to fill in this vital need, Indian Railways has made railway parcel vans available for quick mass transportation by e-commerce entities and other customers including State Governments, he said..

"Then railways decided to run time-tabled special parcel trains to ensure uninterrupted and seamless supply chain of goods and essential commodities like dairy products, medical equipments and medicines on several routes during the nationwide lockdown. It has also offered its unhindered services of parcel trains for nationwide transportation of essential commodities and other goods required to meet the needs of citizens of the nation.

“Zonal railways are regularly identifying and notifying routes for these parcel special trains. Presently these trains are being operated on sixty-five routes. These routes have been identified as regular connectivity between major cities of the country, viz Delhi, Mumbai, Kolkata, Chennai, Bengaluru and Hyderabad,” a senior official said.

“Connectivity from state-capitals/important cities to all parts of the state, ensuring connectivity to the North-eastern part of the country, supply of milk and dairy products from surplus regions (Gujarat, AP) to high demand regions and upply of other essential items (agricultural inputs, medicines, medical equipment, etc) from producing regions to other parts of the country,” he added.

The Indian Railways on Tuesday announced that all passenger train services including premium, mail, express, passenger, and suburban trains will remain cancelled till May 3 in continuation of the measures taken in the wake of COVID-19 lockdown. However, in order to ensure the essential supplies in various parts of the country, movement of goods and parcel trains will continue.

The ministry said that no booking of any type of tickets, including e-tickets shall be done till further advice. However, facility of online cancellation will remain functional for ticket bookings.

Title: Muslim performes last rites of elderly Hindu woman who died of old age
Article:
Amidst covdi19 scare, Madhya Pradesh exhibited an example of brotherhood as Muslim locals performed last rites of an elderly Hindu woman who died of old age on Wednesday morning and her kin could not reach the city due to lockdown.

The incident comes close on the heels of another such example from South Toda Indore where Muslims had taken part in funeral of Hindu woman Draupdi Bai after her sons had no means to perform last rites.The incident in Bhopal was reported from Tila Jamalpura area of Bhopal. The woman had died of old age reasons and after her demise, her relatives could not reach her home due to prohibitive guidelines amid covid19 scare.On this, local Muslims came forward and arranged the funeral procession with the family of the woman. A video of the said funeral procession also went viral in which the Muslims were seen carrying the woman on their shoulders wearing skull cap and masks.

Later exChief Minister Kamal Nath too tweeted the incident terming the same an example of Ganga Jamni tahjib of the country which signifies communal harmony.

These incidents have taken place amid growing corona scare in state. On Wednesday, the total number of positive cases surged to 938 in Madhya Pradesh with Indore reporting 133 fresh cases and its tally reached to 544 while Bhopal’s total positive cases were 167.

Title: MP Govt rolls back decision of notifying BMHRC as reserved hospital for Corona patients
Article:
In a major relief to thousands of victims of 1984 Bhopal gas tragedy, MP Government on Wednesday rolled back an earlier decision of notifying Bhopal Memorial Hospital and Research Centre (BMHRC) as reserved hospital for covid19 patients.

This decision came after massive resentment from gas victims and one of the organisations, Bhopal Group for Action and Information moving high court on the said decision early on Wednesday.

Following lockdown ordered on March 24, the MP government had issued orders reserving BMHRC only for covid19 patients and all the gas affected patients were removed from the hospital immediately including those critically ill who were shifted to other hospitals.Faiz Ahmed KIdwai, Commissioner Health department on Wednesday evening issued an order rolling back earlier orders and reinstating BMHRC’s earlier status.

The order added that the hospital would only be used for testing samples of covdi19 suspects. Early in the day, treating the petition as urgent matter, the HC had taken up immediate hearing and served notices to Centre and state.

The gas victims’ organiations had alleged that converting the BMHRC into covdi19 patients could endanger lives of thousands of gas victims.

“Gas victims hope the OPD and emergency services of BMHRC would be restored from Thursday onwards,” said Rachna Dhingra of BGAI.

She underlined the fact that four gas victims died for lack of treatment after BMHRC was taken over by the district administration post March 24 and added five others who died of corona also were gas affected people.

Title: BRIEF
Article:
TAFE Group donates 2 cr to MP relief fund

Bhopal:The TAFE Group – Tractors and Farm Equipment Limited, manufacturer of Eicher and Massey Ferguson tractors, donates ? 2 Crores to the Madhya Pradesh Chief Minister’s Relief Fund to support the MP Government’s fight against COVID-19. Since the lockdown, various manufacturing facilities of the TAFE Group have been involved in distribution of food, medical supplies and personal protection equipment to law enforcement officers, sanitation workers, local poor and migrant workers around its area of operations. The effect of the Coronavirus outbreak during the Rabi season is likely to have an adverse impact on the livelihood of small and marginal farmers, and it is with a view to assist them in overcoming this distress that TAFE has also initiated a unique free tractor rental scheme in select states.

CM orders probe into case under ESMA Act

Bhopal: Chief Minister Shivraj Singh Chouhan has taken seriously the media reports of not hospitalizing a patient in who came in critical condition in Indore and Khandwa. Chouhan has directed Additional Chief Secretary, Health Shri Mohammad Suleman to immediately order a probe into the case under the ESMA Act. The Chief Minister has said that if the news is found correct after investigation, strict action will be taken against the concerned medical institution.

Title: Lockdown to continue, review on April 21: CM
Article:
Chief Minister Bhupesh Baghel on Wednesday said to contain the spread of the coronavirus pandemic, the lockdown in the state will continue, and a decision will be taken based on a review on the prevailing conditions on April 21.

The districts where the coronavirus pandemic is under control, lockdown relaxations protocol will be extended after a review, the CM said.

In his message to the people of the state, Baghel said now the need is to strictly implement the lockdown, wear masks, wash hands regularly and maintain physical distance.

“It is testing time for one and all, but with the cooperation of the people, it can be controlled, the way it has been continuing with people’s awareness and self-confidence,” he said.

He further said that the state government has taken a pledge that no one in time of this crises sleeps hungry for which free ration is being distributed in advance for two months.

New ration cards are being issued on a war-footing, Baghel said.

The migrant labourers even from the other states are being also taken care of, he said.

“They should remain here, considering the relief camps as their home,” the CM said.

Soon testing for Covid-19 will start at the Raipur medical college in addition to the ones at AIIMS, Raipur and Jagdalpur, which will further enhance testing capacity, he said.

He further said that non-government and civil societies are doing a commendable job but they should work in coordination with the district administration.

Lockdown to continue, review on April 21: CM

STAFF REPORTER n

RAIPUR

Chief Minister Bhupesh Baghel on Wednesday said to contain the spread of the coronavirus pandemic, the lockdown in the state will continue, and a decision will be taken based on a review on the prevailing conditions on April 21.

The districts where the coronavirus pandemic is under control, lockdown relaxations protocol will be extended after a review, the CM said.

In his message to the people of the state, Baghel said now the need is to strictly implement the lockdown, wear masks, wash hands regularly and maintain physical distance.

“It is testing time for one and all, but with the cooperation of the people, it can be controlled, the way it has been continuing with people’s awareness and self-confidence,” he said.

He further said that the state government has taken a pledge that no one in time of this crises sleeps hungry for which free ration is being distributed in advance for two months.

New ration cards are being issued on a war-footing, Baghel said.

The migrant labourers even from the other states are being also taken care of, he said.

“They should remain here, considering the relief camps as their home,” the CM said.

Soon testing for Covid-19 will start at the Raipur medical college in addition to the ones at AIIMS, Raipur and Jagdalpur, which will further enhance testing capacity, he said.

He further said that non-government and civil societies are doing a commendable job but they should work in coordination with the district administration.

Title: 29,683 new ration cards issued in state
Article:
To prevent people from getting infected with COVID-19 amidst the lockdown, free food grains of two months is being distributed to all the impoverished families in the state on the instructions of chief minister Bhupesh Baghel, an official release here said.

The chief minister has asked all the collectors of the state to provide food grains to all the people of the districts on time.

Amid the lockdown, the state food department is issuing new ration cards to the eligible beneficiaries whose ration cards were either not prepared people whose names are missing, are also being added, a release said.

A total of 29,683 new ration cards have been made in the state since the start of the lockdown and the names of more than 44,394 new members have been added to the re-prepared ration cards, it said.

Officials of the food department said the state government is distributing lump-sum rice for the months of April and May to the ration card holders of Antyodaya, priority, single destitute, disabled and Annapurna categories.

Apart from this, rice is also being distributed to the general category ration card holders at a discounted rate of ?10 per kg. Proper management of food grains is being done by the state government with sensitivity and readiness for the people of the state as well as the labourers and the stranded migrant workers in the state due to the lockdown.

Until now, 8.82 lakh people have been provided food and more than 8.75 lakh people have been provided free ration through the district administration by the food department during the lockdown.

Food department secretary Dr Kamalpreet Singh has instructed the district collectors that the process of issuing ration cards should be a continuous process.

Therefore, on receipt of an application from the beneficiaries for issuing a ration card, it should be issued immediately.

To provide relief to the people during the lockdown, 3,086 new ration cards were issued in Raipur district, out of which 2,582 are BPL and 504 APL cards.

Names of 4,983 members of the APL and BPL categories were added to the ration card in Raipur district.

Some 7,418 new ration cards were issued in Durg district—the highest in the state—out of which 987 BPL and 6431 APL ration cards were added, taking the total number of ration cards in Durg to 9,963, the release said.

Title: Four more COVID-19 patients discharged
Article: Four more people, who were infected with Covid-19, were on Wednesday discharged from the AIIMS, Raipur, after they fully recovered from the infection, health officials said. “Four male patients of aged 22, 31, 47 and 52 years, all residents of Katghora, were discharged after all of their reports were found to be satisfactory,” communication officer, AIIMS, Raipur, HS Sharma said. Notably, Katghora is currently the hotspot of Covid-19 infection in the state. With the positive development, the numbers of Covid-19 patients in Chhattisgarh has been reduced to 16. On Tuesday, three patients were discharged from the AIIMS, Raipur.

Title: With surge in cases, TN strengthens testing facilities
Article:
Employing effective clinical management strategies, the Government of Tamil Nadu has succeeded in stabilising the number of patients afflicted with coronavirus in the State, according to Dr C Vijaya Baskar, Minister for health.

Speaking to journalists after a lengthy meeting presided over by Chief Minister Edappadi Palaniswami at Fort Saint George, Dr Baskar, himself a qualified medical doctor said that Tamil Nadu has emerged as the State with the maximum number of testing laboratories (26) capable of testing samples from 5,320 persons per day.

“Ours is the State with the maximum number of laboratories in the country,” said the Minister who was accompanied by Dr Beela Rajesh, the secretary of health and family welfare during the media briefing.

Dr Baskar said that 38 persons tested positive for coronavirus on Wednesday and the number of patients in the State stood at 1,242.

He also disclosed that by Wednesday 118 persons who were undergoing treatment in various hospitals in the State for Covid-19 were discharged. “Two persons succumbed to the coronavirus on Wednesday taking the number of deaths in the State to 14.

The Minister said that he chose to brief the media to set the records right in the backdrop of the allegations levelled by M K Stalin, Leader of opposition and president of the DMK. Stalin had said in a statement on Tuesday that the State was thoroughly unprepared for the pandemic

though there were enough indications about the impending mishap.

Elsewhere in the State, the police and health

officials heaved a sigh of relief as the police took into custody the New Delhi based youth who had tested positive for coronavirus and had escaped from the general hospital in Villupuramlast week. The youth was taken in to custody by Police from Chengalpettu district following intelligence input provided by the local informants.

Dr Baskar in his press briefing also disclosed that though coronavirus struck the State only after it was reported in Kerala, Tamil Nadu had made elaborate arrangements to tackle and prevent the contagious disease.

The number of patients in the State shot up only by the last week of March as a fall out of the arrival of people from single source point (the Delhi meet of Tablighi Jamaat), he said.

Title: 3,700 foreigners return home from Mumbai amid lockdown
Article:
Amid the continued lockdown, Chhatrapati Shivaji Maharaj International Airport (CSMIA), managed by GVK- Mumbai International Airport Ltd (MIAL) has -- in an effort to help the stranded foreigners return to their home countries -- has evacuated over 3700 passengers with 20 repatriation flights between March 25 and April 14 2020.

Working in tandem with the aviation community and the respective embassies, the CSMIA has facilitated the operation of flights carrying the stranded passengers from Mumbai to London, Atlanta, Frankfurt, Singapore, Paris and Tokyo amongst other international destinations.

The CSMIA said that it had taken all the precautionary measures to ensure passenger safety while boarding and arriving at the airport. “The airport has put up a stringent screening process right from the time passengers enter the airport to the time they board their flight, and the same process has been implemented for the arriving passengers as well,” a CSMIA release said

“Post the Government announcing the lockdown in India following the coronavirus outbreak and suspension of commercial passenger flight, the airport has been operating with a curtailed staff and working endlessly to handle cargo flights, charter flights, military aircraft and freighter services,” the release said.

According to CSMIA, it has – in “this unprecedented time”-- maintained seamless cargo operations and has managed close to 240 cargo flights movements over the lockdown period that commenced on March 25 2020,

“The cargo operations at CSMIA have recorded the highest number of exports and import delivery of cargo in a single day in India.

“CSMIA has taken all the precautionary measures to help and support the country to come out of these gloomy days, the airport release added.

Title: Meghalaya doctor dies, first such death in State
Article:
A senior doctor in Meghalaya John L. Sailo Ryntathiang, who tested positive for nCoV two days back, on Wednesday succumbed to COVID-19 registering the first coronavirus death in the hill State, officials said.

Confirming the death of the doctor, Meghalaya Chief Minister Conrad K. Sangma said: "I am deeply saddened to inform that the first COVID-19 positive patient in Meghalaya passed away this morning (Wednesday). My heartfelt condolences to his family and loved ones. May his soul rest in peace."

Title: 9 deaths, 232 new infections in Maha
Article:
On a day there was a small drop in the number of deaths but infections continued to be alarming, as many as nine persons succumbed to Covid-19 taking the total number of deaths in Maharashtra to 187 and the number of infected cases rose by 232-- from 2684 to 2916 --in the State.

Of the total deaths, Pune accounted for six deaths, while Mumbai and Akola reported two deaths and one death respectively.

With the fresh cases, the total number of deaths in the State rose to 187 and in Mumbai to 114.

Of the nine deaths reported on Wednesday, six were men and three women. Four of the deceased were aged over 60 years, while three deceased were in the age group 40 to 60 years. The two remaining deceased were below 40 years. Six out of these nine deceased (72%) had high-risk comorbidities such as diabetes, blood pressure, asthma, heart disease. Of total 232 infected cases reported, Mumbai accounted for 114, taking the total number of cases in the metropolis to 1896.

“Out of 52,000 laboratory samples, 48198 were negative and 2684 have been tested positive for coronavirus until today,” a state medical bulletin said.

“A total 5394 surveillance squads were working today across the state and surveillance of nearly 20 lakh population was done,” the bulletin said Meanwhile, the Birhanmumbai Municipal Corporation (BMC) has held 100 fever clinics from April 5 to 14 in which Of the 3929 people have screened,1541 swabs collected from suspected cases.

Similarly, on the contact tracing front, 857 cases have been detected as a result of contact tracing.

Meanwhile, as many as 33,636 Premises (Govt/semi govt premises, MCGM premises, Home quarantine premises, Covid positive patient premises, other premises) have been sanitized as per GOI guidelines till April 14.

“All citizens who are having diabetes, hypertension , heart diseases like chronic illnesses should be advised to stay strictly at home .Those on treatment for diabetes and hypertension should continue their medications so that the illness will remain under control,” the BMC stated in its advisory. “Elderly as well as citizens with co-morbidities , if develop even slightest symptoms like fever, dry cough, sore throat, mild breathlessness should immediately report to nearest MCGM corona health centre for treatment,” the advisory added.

Title: J&K: Grave violations amid lockdown a concern
Article:
Grave violations on day one of the second phase of lockdown in Jammu on Wednesday shifted the focus on the Government agencies working on ground zero in containing the spread of coronavirus across twin cities of Srinagar and Jammu.
